46545465||Burberry Brit Eau de Toilette Fragrances for Women and Men Fragrances for a modern English spirit—women’s light eau de toilette with lime and men’s laid-back woody scent At his Hampshire shop in the 1850s, Thomas Burberry outfitted hunters and fishermen in rugged gear. Rain was a real misery for the outdoorsmen, so Burberry set out to create an alternative to an umbrella or the shade of an elephant. By 1888, he’d secured the patent for his design: a breathable cotton blend wound so tightly it could resist moisture and rips. Officially, it was called gabardine, but in common parlance, hunters, farmers, pub keepers, and even King Edward VII called it “Burberry.” At the onset of World War I, the inventor used the fabric for a waterproof trench coat literally for the trenches, fitted with the necessary epaulets and D-rings for an artillery-facing soldier. The trench’s style caught on and, decorated with Burberry’s signature tartan print, remains a staple of the brand today. Despite these ties to tradition, Burberry’s creative team lives by the motto  , Latin for “forward.” Classic time-tested shapes are updated with modern details such as statement buttons, metallic fabrics, and seasonal colors. Perfumers Carlos Benaim and Sophie Labbe reimagined Bvlgari’s classic Jasmin Noir fragrance, making it lighter and fresher for everyday wear Spelled with a   but pronounced as a  , the Bvlgari brand began as a small silver shop in Rome in 1884. Founder Sotirio Bulgari came from an ancient family of Greek silversmiths; today, third generation family members carry on the family tradition of transforming raw precious elements into sparkling statement necklaces. Each piece begins with a sketch, as designers assess the color, brilliance, wearability, and je ne sais quoi. In an interview with the  , Nicola Bulgari said, “Each piece has its own philosophy.” Though he draws inspiration from architecture around the world—from India to Columbus, Indiana—he says, “I don’t like the idea of a global style … the same things all over the world. Founder Sotirio Bulgari came from an ancient family of Greek silversmiths; today, third generation family members carry on the family tradition of transforming raw precious elements into sparkling statement necklaces. Each piece begins with a sketch, as designers assess the color, brilliance, wearability, and je ne sais quoi. In an interview with the  , Nicola Bulgari said, “Each piece has its own philosophy.” Though he draws inspiration from architecture around the world—from India to Columbus, Indiana—he says, “I don’t like the idea of a global style … the same things all over the world. Citrus aromatic fragrance opens with notes such as juniper and grapefruit, then reveals a heart of rosemary, Brazilian rosewood, and pepper The names Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana are synonymous with high fashion, though that was not always the case. In the 1980s, the young designers corralled anyone they could into loft spaces and even fast-food restaurants (with burger-shaped invitations no less) they’d transformed into makeshift show rooms. From the beginning, “the boys” played with juxtaposition, contrasting masculine versus feminine, virgin versus harlot in the same designs. In ‘85, the pair made their Milan Fashion Week debut as part of a young talent showcase and never looked back. The international brand has made a name for itself by subverting fashion tropes. Corset dresses and leopard prints are transformed into sophisticated and wearable pieces. Perhaps most famously, the pair redefined women’s suiting with menswear-inspired shapes and tailoring. In addition to clothes, fragrances and other accessories perpetuate the brand’s baroque charm. Madonna, who recognized the pair early on and wore their designs for her 1993 Girlie Show tour commented “Their clothes are sexy with a sense of humor—like me.” Citrus aromatic fragrance FiFi Awards: 2008 Fragrance of the Year, Men’s Prestige Top notes of Sicilian mandarin, juniper, grapefruit, and bergamot Heart notes of rosemary, Brazilian rosewood, and pepper Base notes of musk, oakmoss, and incense Launched in 2007 2.5 fl. oz. spray bottle ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Men's Fragrance (5,084)

The designer gained notoriety for hypersuggestive commercials for everything from blue jeans to perfume, launching the careers of models like Brooke Shields and Kate Moss in the process. But what has kept his brand relevant for over 40 years is its classic, impeccably tailored clothing. Frustrated with the lack of options for the modern working woman, Karan launched a collection of separates that could mix-and-match around a basic black bodysuit. Though it sounds simple,   wrote that the debut collection, “forever changed the way professional women outfit themselves.” Tellingly, DKNY clothes regularly appeared in the landmark 1980s show,  , which portrayed a female TV journalist. Though Karan excelled at designing for strong women, in 1991, she introduced a menswear line, and in 1993, she became the first woman to win a CFDA Menswear Designer of the Year award. 45061018||Jimmy Choo Eau de Parfum for Women (1.3 Fl. Oz. or 2 Fl. Oz.) Eau de parfum fragrance for women combines citrus and sweet notes for a bold, elegant scent When Jimmy Choo made his first pair of shoes at age 11, the task was long overdue. “When I first started,” he said, “My father wouldn’t let me make a shoe. Instead, he said: ‘Sit and watch, sit and watch.’ For months and months, I did that.” As an adult, the Malaysian-born designer moved to London to attend college and then set up a small shop in London’s East End. He built a following of celebrity clients, including Princess Diana and Miss Piggy, who especially appreciated shopping in the tucked away shop.  Jimmy Choo’s reputation for style, craftsmanship, and surprising comfort caught the eye of a shoe-obsessed editor at British  , and the shop was transformed into an international brand. The shoes became so popular that  ’s fictional clotheshorse Carrie Bradshaw filled her closets with Choos, and it’s rumored that Cate Blanchett decided not to wear Choos to the 1999 Oscars because she feared they’d get more attention than she would. As the brand’s popularity exploded, accessories, menswear, and fragrances were added, and the brand has scooped up numerous awards including the British Fashion Council’s Accessory Designer of the Year in 2000, and Designer Brand of the Year in 2008. 47687446||Issey Miyake L'Eau D'Issey Pour Homme Fragrances for Men From luxury designer Issey Miyake, these masculine fragrances can provide men with a new signature scent Issey Miyake doesn’t believe in fashion. He doesn’t believe in “gorgeous clothes.” Instead, he says, what he believes in is “a human being and a piece of cloth.” His first pieces were rooted in his native Japan, including revivals of traditional quilted pieces, such as the  , made from scraps, and the  . He began his work with the goal of breathing life back into Japan, which he saw “culturally obliterated” after the atomic bomb was dropped on his hometown of Hiroshima. He focused his designs on bright color, unique texture, and above all, functionality. After studying in Paris and New York, he began to experiment with pleating, working to twist and stitch in new and innovative ways. His goal was to find a pleat style that wouldn’t restrict movement and that would be easy to care for, and that gave birth to the Pleats Please line of apparel. In 1983, he told  , “I want to find out what clothing might be.” He has experimented with clothing the customers themselves cut at their preferred length, dresses that resemble paper lanterns, and two pairs of pants sewn together so you and your imaginary friend can be literally joined at the hip. Although his brand has appeared in   and Paris fashion shows every year since 1973, Miyake has always meant to appeal to a wider audience, emphasizing versatility and claiming the motto, “Clothes for everyone, not just a few.” A woody aquatic fragrance Top notes of yuzu, bergamot, lemon, and tarragon Middle notes of nutmeg and water lily Base notes of tobacco, sandalwood, cedar, vetiver, and musk Launched: 1994 Winner of FiFi Awards for 1996 Fragrance of The Year in Men’s Luxury 2011 Fragrance Hall of Fame Size: 1.3oz. or 6.7oz. 47766642||Gucci by Gucci Pour Homme Eau de Toilette for Men (1.7 or 3.0 fl. oz.) Modern chypre woody fragrance for men with notes of bergamot, cypress, tobacco leaves, and amber  In the late 1800s, Guccio Gucci worked as a bellhop for The Savoy hotel in London. Carrying heavy luggage stuffed with fine clothing and early-edition paper e-readers, he noticed that Tuscan luggage was a favorite of the wealthy families who visited the hotel. He returned to Florence and opened his own leather goods workshop and store in 1921. Business boomed. Artisans designed a diamond-printed bag and the interlocking G logo—both icons of this brand to this day. By the 1960s and ’70s, the brand’s customers included Audrey Hepburn, Grace Kelly, Jackie O, and Queen Elizabeth II. In 1979, the New York Times wrote that Gucci’s G insignia was “a status symbol recognized around the world.”  Today, Gucci continues to produce signature items such as a bamboo-handled handbag, a Jackie O handbag, and penny loafers. Their modern menswear combines classic European styles with impeccable tailoring. Women’s apparel borrows menswear looks, such as suits and blazers, and updates them with plush fabrics or edgy silhouettes. 48056235||Burberry Brit, Brit Sheer, or Brit Rhythm Eau de Toilette for Women; Assorted Sizes These fragrances feature three unique scents that pair sweet top notes of lavender and mandarin orange with base notes of musk and amber At his Hampshire shop in the 1850s, Thomas Burberry outfitted hunters and fishermen in rugged gear. Rain was a real misery for the outdoorsmen, so Burberry set out to create an alternative to an umbrella or the shade of an elephant. By 1888, he’d secured the patent for his design: a breathable cotton blend wound so tightly it could resist moisture and rips. Officially, it was called gabardine, but in common parlance, hunters, farmers, pub keepers, and even King Edward VII called it “Burberry.” At the onset of World War I, the inventor used the fabric for a waterproof trench coat literally for the trenches, fitted with the necessary epaulets and D-rings for an artillery-facing soldier. The trench’s style caught on and, decorated with Burberry’s signature tartan print, remains a staple of the brand today. Despite these ties to tradition, Burberry’s creative team lives by the motto  , Latin for “forward.” Classic time-tested shapes are updated with modern details such as statement buttons, metallic fabrics, and seasonal colors. 45067319||Lilian Fache 540 1mm Needle Single Head Derma Roller This titanium-tipped derma roller helps the body naturally rejuvenate skin, reducing the look of stretch marks, cellulite, and scarring This single head derma roller is designed to rejuvenate skin and help reduce the look of wrinkles both deep and fine, as well as scars, cellulite, and areas of excessive hair loss. It has hundreds of micro-needles, that, when applied, gently roll over the face to promote natural skin repair. The small handheld device aims to simulate the results of cosmetic surgery, which can cause stress to both your body and your bank account.  Begin by sterilizing the derma roller with an alcohol solution and warm water. Then take the device and gently roll up and down the face with even pressure. Roll left to right on the same areas in a cross-hatching pattern. Repeat and focus on trouble areas, like the mouth, T-zone, and sensitive skin under the eyes. When finished, clean and let air dry.  As you use the roller, hundreds of micro-needles create tiny pin pricks on the skin. This kickstarts the production of elastin and collagen, which work to repair those areas and give skin a naturally youthful look. 47966847||Jean-Paul Gaultier Le Male Eau de Toilette for Men Award-winning scent opens with fresh mint and is followed by scents both fruity and spicy, such as bergamot, lavender, and cumin A Google search for Jean-Paul Gaultier will bring up thousands of websites, many with the words “enfant terrible” in the page preview. The French designer,   says, “is one of those designers whose vivid public persona…is an invaluable part of the brand. So what is shorthand for  ? Breton stripe, peroxided hair, brilliant tailoring—and a cheeky, cheerful irreverence.” Since launching his label in the ‘70s, he’s scuttled gender stereotypes and embraced a degree of sexualized fashion. For Madonna’s Blonde Ambition tour, he designed a cone-shaped brassiere that became nearly as iconic as the singer herself, recently auctioning for $52,000. He designed a skirt for men and paired a hyper-feminine crinoline skirt with a leather jacket for women. His perfumes come in bottles sculpted to resemble the kinds of torsos in magazines behind the gas-station counter.  “I don’t think I was ever concerned with shocking people…I just wanted to show what I found fair or normal or beautiful,” Gaultier said. Though the fearlessness of his work grabs headlines, it’s his meticulous craftsmanship and beautifully transgressive designs that have earned him a reputation as an artist. His pieces have even been on display at the Met and San Francisco’s De Young museum. 47596647||Gucci Guilty Eau de Toilette for Men or Women (1.6 Fl. Oz.) Both the men’s and women’s variations of the Gucci Guilty fragrance have citrus top notes, a floral heart, and a base of lingering patchouli In the late 1800s, Guccio Gucci worked as a bellhop for The Savoy hotel in London. Carrying heavy luggage stuffed with fine clothing and early-edition paper e-readers, he noticed that Tuscan luggage was a favorite of the wealthy families who visited the hotel. He returned to Florence and opened his own leather goods workshop and store in 1921. Business boomed. Artisans designed a diamond-printed bag and the interlocking G logo—both icons of this brand to this day. By the 1960s and ’70s, the brand’s customers included Audrey Hepburn, Grace Kelly, Jackie O, and Queen Elizabeth II. In 1979, the New York Times wrote that Gucci’s G insignia was “a status symbol recognized around the world.” Today, Gucci continues to produce signature items such as a bamboo-handled handbag, a Jackie O handbag, and penny loafers. Their modern menswear combines classic European styles with impeccable tailoring. Women’s apparel borrows menswear looks, such as suits and blazers, and updates them with plush fabrics or edgy silhouettes. 47591660||Viktor & Rolf Flowerbomb Eau de Parfum (1.7 Fl. Oz.) Fresh and sweet fragrances from the Dutch design house Viktor & Rolf, featuring feminine blends of notes like jasmine, rose, and patchouli Ultrahip designers Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren believe “fashion is an antidote to reality, it has the power of transformation and provides a window to a different, magical world.” This belief in fantasy has been apparent since the Dutch wunderkinds’ first Parisian show in 1993, where they upset couture ideals with a series of edgy, reconstructed ball gowns. The inventive designers gather inspiration from seemingly disparate sources—Golden Age portraiture, De Stijl functionalism, and experimental designers Elsa Schiaparelli and Yohji Yamamoto, among others—and weave them into complex architectural pieces that teeter between ready-to-wear and the avant-garde.  In recent years, the duo has moved away from the highly fantastical world of couture into a more mainstream presence. They developed a popular fragrance with L’Oréal and debuted a well-received collection at H&M. Horsting expanded on this when he said, “A fashion show is for an elite and this elite … will look for the new dress … of the season, which is what fashion’s about. But we would like fashion to be about more than that.” Fresh and sweet fragrance for women Top notes of bergamot and green tea Heart notes of sambac jasmine, centifolia rose, freesia, and cattleya orchid Base notes of musk and patchouli Introduced in 2005 1.7 fl. oz. The Versace fashion house defines its essence as “irreverent luxury expressed by impactful shapes and colors.” But as a   writer once shrewdly observed, the fashion house doesn’t create avant-garde or elegant clothing. Instead “… it makes clothes for red-carpet photo calls in Cannes and parties aboard a rap mogul’s mega-yacht at anchor in Monaco.” Company founder Gianni Versace was also the first to harness the power of celebrity and supermodels at his fashion shows. By combining these with his sexy, bold aesthetic, he helped irrevocably link the Versace name and aesthetic with an aspirational lifestyle. 47616924||Dolce & Gabbana Light Blue Eau de Toilettes for Men or Women (Multiple Sizes Available) Refreshing eau de toilettes for men and women evoke the spirit of warm summer days spent on the seashore The names Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana are synonymous with high fashion, though that was not always the case. In the 1980s, the young designers corralled anyone they could into loft spaces and even fast-food restaurants (with burger-shaped invitations no less) they’d transformed into makeshift show rooms. From the beginning, “the boys” played with juxtaposition, contrasting masculine versus feminine, virgin versus harlot in the same designs. In ‘85, the pair made their Milan Fashion Week debut as part of a young talent showcase and never looked back. The international brand has made a name for itself by subverting fashion tropes. Corset dresses and leopard prints are transformed into sophisticated and wearable pieces. Perhaps most famously, the pair redefined women’s suiting with menswear-inspired shapes and tailoring. In addition to clothes, fragrances and other accessories perpetuate the brand’s baroque charm. Madonna, who recognized the pair early on and wore their designs for her 1993 Girlie Show tour commented “Their clothes are sexy with a sense of humor—like me.” Fruity and floral fragrance Fragrance notes: lime and cedar Application: eau de toilette Gender: women’s Capacity: 0.84, 1.6, or 3.3 fl. oz. 47895725||Issey Miyake L'Eau d'Issey For Women or Men Light refreshing fragrances for men and women make a subtle, attractive addition to fragrance collections Issey Miyake doesn’t believe in fashion. He doesn’t believe in “gorgeous clothes.” Instead, he says, what he believes in is “a human being and a piece of cloth.” His first pieces were rooted in his native Japan, including revivals of traditional quilted pieces, such as the  , made from scraps, and the  . He began his work with the goal of breathing life back into Japan, which he saw “culturally obliterated” after the atomic bomb was dropped on his hometown of Hiroshima. He focused his designs on bright color, unique texture, and above all, functionality. After studying in Paris and New York, he began to experiment with pleating, working to twist and stitch in new and innovative ways. His goal was to find a pleat style that wouldn’t restrict movement and that would be easy to care for, and that gave birth to the Pleats Please line of apparel. In 1983, he told  , “I want to find out what clothing might be.” He has experimented with clothing the customers themselves cut at their preferred length, dresses that resemble paper lanterns, and two pairs of pants sewn together so you and your imaginary friend can be literally joined at the hip. Although his brand has appeared in   and Paris fashion shows every year since 1973, Miyake has always meant to appeal to a wider audience, emphasizing versatility and claiming the motto, “Clothes for everyone, not just a few.” Inspired by the spray of waterfall, floral fragrances, and a springtime forest Launched: 1992 FiFI Awards: 2011 Fragrance Hall of Fame Available in 1.6oz. or 3.3oz. Instead, he said: ‘Sit and watch, sit and watch.’ For months and months, I did that.” As an adult, the Malaysian-born designer moved to London to attend college and then set up a small shop in London’s East End. He built a following of celebrity clients, including Princess Diana and Miss Piggy, who especially appreciated shopping in the tucked away shop.  Jimmy Choo’s reputation for style, craftsmanship, and surprising comfort caught the eye of a shoe-obsessed editor at British  , and the shop was transformed into an international brand. The shoes became so popular that  ’s fictional clotheshorse Carrie Bradshaw filled her closets with Choos, and it’s rumored that Cate Blanchett decided not to wear Choos to the 1999 Oscars because she feared they’d get more attention than she would. As the brand’s popularity exploded, accessories, menswear, and fragrances were added, and the brand has scooped up numerous awards including the British Fashion Council’s Accessory Designer of the Year in 2000, and Designer Brand of the Year in 2008. This luxurious bath gel and nourishing body milk are infused with fragrance notes of black cherry, rose, almond, licorice, and black tea  In 1828, Pierre-François-Pascal Guerlain opened a perfume shop in Paris. Behind his simple storefront, he began to dabble in perfume-making himself. By the 1850s, he was bottling custom fragrances for royalty, including Eau Imperiale for Empress Eugenie, wife of Napoleon III; Queen Isabelle of Spain; Sissi, the Empress of Austria; and the Grand Duke Alexandrovich. Queen Victoria wore “Jicky,” and 100 years later, so did Jackie O.  Today—five generations later—the company’s in-house “nose” continues to create new fragrances. They also introduced a line of skincare products and makeup.   writes that the company “still, today, has all the elegant, exclusive cachet it had during the Second Empire.” La Petite Robe Noire Body Milk (6.7 fl. oz.) While working as a bookkeeper for a pharmaceuticals company in New York City, Arden became fascinated by the science of skincare and cosmetics. 45269763||Clinique Quickliner for Eyes (0.7 Oz.) Silky-smooth automatic eyeliner pencil gives your eyes a natural or dramatic-looking boost with a built-in smudging tool Clinique’s Quickliner is a two-in-one cosmetic; it can create precise winged styles with its pencil tip or dramatic smoky looks with the built-in smudge tool. No sharpening or whittling with a pointy rock is ever necessary, since the automatic pencil simply twists up to refresh the pigment. The tool’s two secure caps make it a safe addition to purses and totes, so you can bring the eyeliner along for touch-ups at work or on dates. In 1968, Clinique was founded on the philosophy that you don’t have to be born with great skin—it can be acquired. Ever since, skincare professionals have paired up with dermatologists to create allergy-tested and fragrance-free products that are gentle on the skin but still effective. To ensure its high standards, every Clinique item is tested 12 times on 600 people, and If a single application causes a reaction, the product is scrapped. Clinique also formulates each product to address an individual skin type or concern instead of hawking universal solutions to nuanced problems. Still, most of the brand’s care routines follow the original, time-tested three-step formula: cleanse, exfoliate, moisturize. Since its launch, Clinique has branched out to cosmetics, creating highly pigmented lipsticks, eye shadows, and foundation that are just as good for your skin. 0.7 oz. pencil Silky application Smudge tool at opposite end Automatic pencil twists up No sharpening required ||Health & Beauty > Cosmetics > Eye Makeup

The chemist was so inspired by the beauty that he named his company for the place and made those flowers its emblem. Stars such as Isabella Rossellini, Kate Winslet, and Penélope Cruz have all appeared beside the Lancôme rose, epitomizing the natural femininity and immunity to pollen touted by the respected cosmetic brand. “True luxury is efficacy,” Youcef Nabi has told  . As the current head of Lancôme, Nabi is well aware that, to remain relevant in this industry, a brand must deliver tangible results. Though Lancôme’s cosmetic products—such as Définicils mascara and Juicy Tubes lip gloss—remain industry-wide favorites, its science-based skincare line has earned a cult following of its own. This focus on effectiveness remains at the forefront of the nearly 80-year-old company’s consciousness. 47922787||True Isaac Mizrahi Lip Wardrobe Set Crimson (4-Piece) Add pops of red-hot color to any outfit with a crimson pout—created with this set’s definer, color, and gloss—plus matching nail lacquer At age 11, Isaac Mizrahi toiled over the 1970s sewing machine that he purchased with babysitting money. He recalls, “I felt like a total outcast. I used to sit and make these puppets … Everybody was worried about me.” Upon transferring from a religious day school to a performing-arts high school, he underwent a transformation. Mizrahi took classes at Parsons The New School for Design while taking acting classes during the day. By the early ’80s, the boy from Brooklyn had a film credit for   and was an apprentice for Perry Ellis. It wouldn’t be long before   would dub him “a kind of Seventh Avenue Oscar Wilde.” From his earliest collections, Mizrahi has been inspired by vivid colors and bold prints. His unorthodox design methods, including consulting with a ouija board, have inspired equally unorthodox business practices. In 2004, the brand launched a collection with Target alongside a new haute couture line. Mizrahi combined pieces from both collections in a runway show, stating, “My goal is that you won’t always be able to tell the difference between what is Target and what is couture.” The show was a huge success and inspired a revolutionary trend in the industry toward affordable fashion. Mizrahi remains committed to making luxury attainable, whether it’s his clothes, accessories, fragrances, or beauty products. As his label says, “Inside every woman is a star.” Lip color (0.12 oz.) 45874141||Guerlain Gloss d'Enfer Guerlain gloss gives lips a lustrous finish and colors them in warm tones to match the bright flowers of spring and juicy fruits of summer Both the warm hues of this gloss and its scent—which includes notes of lemon, orange, bergamot, rose, iris, vanilla, and tonka bean—complement the sensual, intangible qualities of spring and summer. Apply a coat of Gloss d’Enfer over matte lipstick for both intensity of color and a glossy finish. In 1828, Pierre-François-Pascal Guerlain opened a perfume shop in Paris. Behind his simple storefront, he began to dabble in perfume-making himself. By the 1850s, he was bottling custom fragrances for royalty, including Eau Imperiale for Empress Eugenie, wife of Napoleon III; Queen Isabelle of Spain; Sissi, the Empress of Austria; and the Grand Duke Alexandrovich. Queen Victoria wore “Jicky,” and 100 years later, so did Jackie O. Today—five generations later—the company’s in-house “nose” continues to create new fragrances. They also introduced a line of skincare products and makeup.   writes that the company “still, today, has all the elegant, exclusive cachet it had during the Second Empire.” Gives lips a glossy, non-sticky finish and a pop of color Glides on smoothly for easy application Helps keep lips soft and hydrated Size of each lip gloss: 7.5mL Country of origin: France ||Health & Beauty > Cosmetics > Lips

46398396||Clinique Repairwear Laser Focus All Smooth Makeup in #08 (1 Fl. Oz.) Moisturizing serum foundation provides blendable coverage while reducing the appearance of fine lines and wrinkles In 1968, Clinique was founded on the philosophy that you don’t have to be born with great skin—it can be acquired. Ever since, skincare professionals have paired up with dermatologists to create allergy-tested and fragrance-free products that are gentle on the skin but still effective. To ensure its high standards, every Clinique item is tested 12 times on 600 people, and If a single application causes a reaction, the product is scrapped. Clinique also formulates each product to address an individual skin type or concern instead of hawking universal solutions to nuanced problems. Still, most of the brand’s care routines follow the original, time-tested three-step formula: cleanse, exfoliate, moisturize. Since its launch, Clinique has branched out to cosmetics, creating highly pigmented lipsticks, eye shadows, and foundation that are just as good for your skin. Moisturizing serum foundation Helps smooth fine lines and wrinkles Leaves skin softer and more supple Contains SPF 15 Shade #08 (MF/M-N) For Very Dry/Dry Combination skin 1 fl. oz. ||Health & Beauty > Cosmetics > Face Makeup

47913481||True Isaac Mizrahi Perfect Palette with Travel Brushes This complete makeup palette features on-trend colors and convenient travel brushes designed by Isaac Mizrahi for a clean, fashionable look At age 11, Isaac Mizrahi toiled over the 1970s sewing machine that he purchased with babysitting money. He recalls, “I felt like a total outcast. I used to sit and make these puppets … Everybody was worried about me.” Upon transferring from a religious day school to a performing-arts high school, he underwent a transformation. Mizrahi took classes at Parsons The New School for Design while taking acting classes during the day. By the early ’80s, the boy from Brooklyn had a film credit for   and was an apprentice for Perry Ellis. It wouldn’t be long before   would dub him “a kind of Seventh Avenue Oscar Wilde.” From his earliest collections, Mizrahi has been inspired by vivid colors and bold prints. His unorthodox design methods, including consulting with a ouija board, have inspired equally unorthodox business practices. In 2004, the brand launched a collection with Target alongside a new haute couture line. Mizrahi combined pieces from both collections in a runway show, stating, “My goal is that you won’t always be able to tell the difference between what is Target and what is couture.” The show was a huge success and inspired a revolutionary trend in the industry toward affordable fashion. Mizrahi remains committed to making luxury attainable, whether it’s his clothes, accessories, fragrances, or beauty products. As his label says, “Inside every woman is a star.” 4 eye shadows and liner powders 2 highlighters/concealers Powder blush Finishing translucent powder Shadow brush Retractable eyeliner brush Retractable blush brush A selection of on-trend colors to bring out the best in your face Highlighter brightens complexion and conceals blemishes Four colors of eye shadow and liner powder create a variety of fashionable looks Accentuate natural glow with powder blush Even out skin tone with finishing translucent powder Conveniently sized brushes, some with retractable option, are ideal for trips and travel Eye shadow: 0.026oz. Shimmering cream eye color is designed to stay put for up to 16 hours without fading, smudging, or creasing From the very beginning, every aspect of the Shiseido brand has been designed to bridge the gap between East and West. In 1872, Shiseido opened as the first Western-medicine pharmacy in Tokyo. Then the company developed its own line of high-quality hygiene, skincare, and cosmetics products to suit its exclusively Japanese clientele. One of those first original products, Eudermine lotion—nicknamed Shiseido’s Red Water—was introduced in 1897, and it remains a best-seller more than 100 years later, with only a few tweaks for modern-day customers. 0.21 oz. 45874340||Max Factor Kohl Eyeliner Pencil Eyeliner pencil in a variety of neutral or striking colors gives eyes color while helping give them a more defined shape The Max Factor brand grew up alongside the early film industry, when newly minted movie stars needed to trade the theater’s greasepaint for something more lifelike. Max Factor himself came up with a face-paint formula that could deceive the camera’s close-ups, rendering smooth complexions that looked soft and glowing in black-and-white. Painting the likes of Joan Crawford, Clara Bow, and Mary Pickford, Factor and his now-iconic Pan-Cake makeup and “lip pomade” ushered in the age of the glamorous screen siren. In 1920, he made his wares available to the public, allowing women to emulate the icons they saw at the pictures every week. Today, Max Factor is still going strong and continues to introduce game-changing cosmetics, including Lipfinity long-lasting lipstick and False Lash Effect mascara. 45332058||OPI Nail Lacquer Long-lasting, chip-resistant polish decks out nails in on-trend colors OPI nail polishes are well-known for descriptive names like I’m Not Really a Waitress and Tasmanian Devil Made Me Do It, but the company’s own moniker, OPI, isn’t nearly as attention-grabbing. Originally known as Odontorium Products Inc., the company sold dental supplies until the 1980s, when a new owner developed an innovative acrylic-nail system. With that success, the company’s focus shifted solely to nails, and along with an ever-expanding range of hues came a new name, OPI, which is now practically synonymous with high-quality and stylish nail color. 47793734||TRUE Isaac Mizrahi Lip Wardrobe Lip liner, lipstick, and gloss work together to give you the perfect pout; nail lacquer is included to top off the look At age 11, Isaac Mizrahi toiled over the 1970s sewing machine that he purchased with babysitting money. He recalls, “I felt like a total outcast. I used to sit and make these puppets … Everybody was worried about me.” Upon transferring from a religious day school to a performing-arts high school, he underwent a transformation. Mizrahi took classes at Parsons The New School for Design while taking acting classes during the day. By the early ’80s, the boy from Brooklyn had a film credit for   and was an apprentice for Perry Ellis. It wouldn’t be long before   would dub him “a kind of Seventh Avenue Oscar Wilde.” From his earliest collections, Mizrahi has been inspired by vivid colors and bold prints. His unorthodox design methods, including consulting with a ouija board, have inspired equally unorthodox business practices. In 2004, the brand launched a collection with Target alongside a new haute couture line. Mizrahi combined pieces from both collections in a runway show, stating, “My goal is that you won’t always be able to tell the difference between what is Target and what is couture.” The show was a huge success and inspired a revolutionary trend in the industry toward affordable fashion. Mizrahi remains committed to making luxury attainable, whether it’s his clothes, accessories, fragrances, or beauty products. As his label says, “Inside every woman is a star.” Lip definer in Mauve (0.04oz.) Matte lip color in Just Looking (0.12oz.) Sheer lip shine in After Glow (0.12oz.) Nail lacquer in Nutty (0.5oz.) Lip pencil by Shiseido delivers vibrant, long-lasting color in a smooth, lightweight formula  From the very beginning, every aspect of the Shiseido brand has been designed to bridge the gap between East and West. In 1872, Shiseido opened as the first Western-medicine pharmacy in Tokyo. Then the company developed its own line of high-quality hygiene, skincare, and cosmetics products to suit its exclusively Japanese clientele. One of those first original products, Eudermine lotion—nicknamed Shiseido’s Red Water—was introduced in 1897, and it remains a best-seller more than 100 years later, with only a few tweaks for modern-day customers. 46314156||Lancôme Juicy Tubes; 0.5 Oz. This ultra shiny lip gloss by Lancôme glides on easily thanks to its tube tip applicator and provides a sheer wash of color and flavor In 1935, Armand Petitjean found inspiration in the yellow flowers that dotted the grounds of the Château de Lancosme, a castle just outside of Paris. The chemist was so inspired by the beauty that he named his company for the place and made those flowers its emblem. Stars such as Isabella Rossellini, Kate Winslet, and Penélope Cruz have all appeared beside the Lancôme rose, epitomizing the natural femininity and immunity to pollen touted by the respected cosmetic brand. “True luxury is efficacy,” Youcef Nabi has told  . As the current head of Lancôme, Nabi is well aware that, to remain relevant in this industry, a brand must deliver tangible results. Though Lancôme’s cosmetic products—such as Définicils mascara and Juicy Tubes lip gloss—remain industry-wide favorites, its science-based skincare line has earned a cult following of its own. This focus on effectiveness remains at the forefront of the nearly 80-year-old company’s consciousness. Revlon makes a business of staying ahead of the fashion curve. When it debuted in department stores in 1932, Revlon was the first cosmetics company to offer nail enamel in a color other than red. And later, during the 1950s when American women were looking to foreign Hollywood stars for beauty inspiration, Revlon used American-born models in its print ads to help build up US women’s self-images. Throughout the next few decades, Revlon matched the strides women were taking, adding new and interesting products that mirrored women’s growing roles in business and politics. 45874290||Yves Saint Laurent Touche Éclat Radiant Touch Concealer (0.1 Fl. Oz.) Brightening pen brings a touch of radiance to skin and lips, offsetting signs of fatigue and adding beauty-enhancing highlights In 1957, legendary designer Christian Dior calmly passed the reins of his eponymous fashion house to a remarkably young, 21-year-old Yves Saint Laurent. This single act kick-started the boy wonder’s enduring fashion legacy, and he launched his own line in 1962. During the decades that followed, his fame would skyrocket, propelled by groundbreaking, often controversial, designs that turned celebrities, fashion lovers, and fellow designers Miuccia Prada and Giorgio Armani into devout fans. Of his lasting influence, designer Christian Lacroix once quipped, “He’s got the form of Chanel with the opulence of Dior and the wit of Schiaparelli.” Saint Laurent was both lauded and slandered for this ingenuity and his often-paradoxical themes. Culling influence from cultural movements, the Beats, and political protests unfolding around the world during the ‘60s and ‘70s, Saint Laurent upset old-world fashion ideals with nearly every collection. He ruffled the feathers of the fashion elite by blending blue-collar garments such as peasant blouses and leather jackets with his couture works. He also outfitted women in tuxedoes and fedoras before it was common. His long-time partner, Pierre Berge, famously summed up Saint Laurent’s legacy in one turn-of-phrase: “Chanel gave women freedom. Yves Saint Laurent gave them power.” Highlighter pen Adds a touch of radiance to skin Visually offsets signs of fatigue, such as under-eye bags For all skin types Color: #2 Luminous Ivory Size: 0.1 fl. oz. In 1968, Clinique was founded on the philosophy that you don’t have to be born with great skin—it can be acquired. Ever since, skincare professionals have paired up with dermatologists to create allergy-tested and fragrance-free products that are gentle on the skin but still effective. To ensure its high standards, every Clinique item is tested 12 times on 600 people, and If a single application causes a reaction, the product is scrapped. Clinique also formulates each product to address an individual skin type or concern instead of hawking universal solutions to nuanced problems. Still, most of the brand’s care routines follow the original, time-tested three-step formula: cleanse, exfoliate, moisturize. Since its launch, Clinique has branched out to cosmetics, creating highly pigmented lipsticks, eye shadows, and foundation that are just as good for your skin. Gently blend into skin for a clearer and more radiant complexion. When Christian Dior was 14 years old, a palm reader at the local fair told him his fortune. She said that after a period of great poverty, he would travel widely and make his fortune from women. Both came true. Despite financial trials following the Great Depression and a serious bout of tuberculosis, Dior rose to become one of the world’s most influential fashion designers. After working under Pierre Balmain, he revolutionized women’s dress in 1947 with his post–World War II “New Look”—a curvaceous silhouette marked by a tiny, defined waist and voluminous midcalf skirt. Dior, an avid gardener, described it by saying, “I drew women-flowers, fine waists like liana and wide skirts like corolla.” The frenzy that followed its introduction helped cement Dior in the annuls of fashion history. Today, the company carries on the powerful name of Christian Dior, leading the industry in womens- and menswear beneath such innovators as Raf Simons and Bill Gaytten. From the very beginning, every aspect of the Shiseido brand has been designed to bridge the gap between East and West. In 1872, Shiseido opened as the first Western-medicine pharmacy in Tokyo. 47881974||TRUE Isaac Mizrahi Lip Gloss Set with Wristlet (3-Piece) Lavish color meets luscious shine in this lip trio, which includes conditioning and shimmering tints for soft, gorgeously glossy lips At age 11, Isaac Mizrahi toiled over the 1970s sewing machine that he purchased with babysitting money. He recalls, “I felt like a total outcast. I used to sit and make these puppets … Everybody was worried about me.” Upon transferring from a religious day school to a performing-arts high school, he underwent a transformation. Mizrahi took classes at Parsons The New School for Design while taking acting classes during the day. By the early ’80s, the boy from Brooklyn had a film credit for   and was an apprentice for Perry Ellis. It wouldn’t be long before   would dub him “a kind of Seventh Avenue Oscar Wilde.” From his earliest collections, Mizrahi has been inspired by vivid colors and bold prints. His unorthodox design methods, including consulting with a ouija board, have inspired equally unorthodox business practices. In 2004, the brand launched a collection with Target alongside a new haute couture line. Mizrahi combined pieces from both collections in a runway show, stating, “My goal is that you won’t always be able to tell the difference between what is Target and what is couture.” The show was a huge success and inspired a revolutionary trend in the industry toward affordable fashion. Mizrahi remains committed to making luxury attainable, whether it’s his clothes, accessories, fragrances, or beauty products. Richly-pigmented lipstick glides on smoothly and resists fading for up to six hours In 1935, Armand Petitjean found inspiration in the yellow flowers that dotted the grounds of the Château de Lancosme, a castle just outside of Paris. The chemist was so inspired by the beauty that he named his company for the place and made those flowers its emblem. Stars such as Isabella Rossellini, Kate Winslet, and Penélope Cruz have all appeared beside the Lancôme rose, epitomizing the natural femininity and immunity to pollen touted by the respected cosmetic brand. “True luxury is efficacy,” Youcef Nabi has told  . As the current head of Lancôme, Nabi is well aware that, to remain relevant in this industry, a brand must deliver tangible results. Though Lancôme’s cosmetic products—such as Définicils mascara and Juicy Tubes lip gloss—remain industry-wide favorites, its science-based skincare line has earned a cult following of its own. This focus on effectiveness remains at the forefront of the nearly 80-year-old company’s consciousness. 0.12 oz. 46398316||Diorskin Star Studio Makeup (1 Fl. Oz.) Skin perfecting studio makeup by Dior helps reduce redness and dark spots for a brighter, more even tone When Christian Dior was 14 years old, a palm reader at the local fair told him his fortune. She said that after a period of great poverty, he would travel widely and make his fortune from women. Both came true. Despite financial trials following the Great Depression and a serious bout of tuberculosis, Dior rose to become one of the world’s most influential fashion designers. After working under Pierre Balmain, he revolutionized women’s dress in 1947 with his post–World War II “New Look”—a curvaceous silhouette marked by a tiny, defined waist and voluminous midcalf skirt. Dior, an avid gardener, described it by saying, “I drew women-flowers, fine waists like liana and wide skirts like corolla.” The frenzy that followed its introduction helped cement Dior in the annuls of fashion history. Today, the company carries on the powerful name of Christian Dior, leading the industry in womens- and menswear beneath such innovators as Raf Simons and Bill Gaytten. Perfecting studio makeup Helps reduce the appearance of redness or dark spots Works to even the complexion Buildable coverage Contains SPF 30 1 fl. oz. 47881901||True Isaac Mizrahi Eyeliner and Mascara Trio Define your lash line with liquid eyeliner and top off with lengthening, thickening mascara to create eye makeup looks for day or night At age 11, Isaac Mizrahi toiled over the 1970s sewing machine that he purchased with babysitting money. He recalls, “I felt like a total outcast. I used to sit and make these puppets … Everybody was worried about me.” Upon transferring from a religious day school to a performing-arts high school, he underwent a transformation. Mizrahi took classes at Parsons The New School for Design while taking acting classes during the day. By the early ’80s, the boy from Brooklyn had a film credit for   and was an apprentice for Perry Ellis. It wouldn’t be long before   would dub him “a kind of Seventh Avenue Oscar Wilde.” From his earliest collections, Mizrahi has been inspired by vivid colors and bold prints. His unorthodox design methods, including consulting with a ouija board, have inspired equally unorthodox business practices. In 2004, the brand launched a collection with Target alongside a new haute couture line. Mizrahi combined pieces from both collections in a runway show, stating, “My goal is that you won’t always be able to tell the difference between what is Target and what is couture.” The show was a huge success and inspired a revolutionary trend in the industry toward affordable fashion. Mizrahi remains committed to making luxury attainable, whether it’s his clothes, accessories, fragrances, or beauty products. 47922764||True Isaac Mizrahi Illuminating Shimmer in Rose Quartz (0.38 oz.) This rosy powder is infused with mineralized pearls, which lend a luminous glow to the cheeks and eyes; purse-sized powder brush included At age 11, Isaac Mizrahi toiled over the 1970s sewing machine that he purchased with babysitting money. He recalls, “I felt like a total outcast. I used to sit and make these puppets … Everybody was worried about me.” Upon transferring from a religious day school to a performing-arts high school, he underwent a transformation. Mizrahi took classes at Parsons The New School for Design while taking acting classes during the day. By the early ’80s, the boy from Brooklyn had a film credit for   and was an apprentice for Perry Ellis. It wouldn’t be long before   would dub him “a kind of Seventh Avenue Oscar Wilde.” From his earliest collections, Mizrahi has been inspired by vivid colors and bold prints. His unorthodox design methods, including consulting with a ouija board, have inspired equally unorthodox business practices. In 2004, the brand launched a collection with Target alongside a new haute couture line. Mizrahi combined pieces from both collections in a runway show, stating, “My goal is that you won’t always be able to tell the difference between what is Target and what is couture.” The show was a huge success and inspired a revolutionary trend in the industry toward affordable fashion. Mizrahi remains committed to making luxury attainable, whether it’s his clothes, accessories, fragrances, or beauty products. As his label says, “Inside every woman is a star.” Illuminating powder (0.38 oz.) Retractable powder brush  0.38 oz. Stars such as Isabella Rossellini, Kate Winslet, and Penélope Cruz have all appeared beside the Lancôme rose, epitomizing the natural femininity and immunity to pollen touted by the respected cosmetic brand. “True luxury is efficacy,” Youcef Nabi has told  . As the current head of Lancôme, Nabi is well aware that, to remain relevant in this industry, a brand must deliver tangible results. Though Lancôme’s cosmetic products—such as Définicils mascara and Juicy Tubes lip gloss—remain industry-wide favorites, its science-based skincare line has earned a cult following of its own. This focus on effectiveness remains at the forefront of the nearly 80-year-old company’s consciousness. Revlon makes a business of staying ahead of the fashion curve. When it debuted in department stores in 1932, Revlon was the first cosmetics company to offer nail enamel in a color other than red. And later, during the 1950s when American women were looking to foreign Hollywood stars for beauty inspiration, Revlon used American-born models in its print ads to help build up US women’s self-images. Throughout the next few decades, Revlon matched the strides women were taking, adding new and interesting products that mirrored women’s growing roles in business and politics. Now, Revlon’s cosmetics line has extended to include Age Defying foundations and Ultra HD lipstick represented through the years by ambassadors from Cindy Crawford to Emma Stone. 44733002||3D Fiber Lashes Transplanting Gel and Green Tea Natural Fibers Mascara This two-step organic process can have your lashes reaching new lengths with all natural fibers for a look that can last from day to night The combination of transplanting gel and natural fiber can add extreme length to your lashes, with a natural and all organic formula that is designed for comfortable long-lasting wear throughout the day.  Slowly coat lashes with transplanting gel as you would regularly apply mascara from the bottom of the baseline to the top. Immediately afterwards, swiftly apply fibers. It is important to do this quickly, because if the gel dries the fibers will not stick. Let dry and then apply another coat of the transplanting gel to seal off lashes. Effect can gently wash off with warm water of facial cleanser.  All natural and organic green tea fibers. 47922464||TRUE Isaac Mizrahi Lip Crayon (4-Piece Set) Smooth and silky lip pencils in rosy and red hues are formulated to provide vibrant and lasting color At age 11, Isaac Mizrahi toiled over the 1970s sewing machine that he purchased with babysitting money. He recalls, “I felt like a total outcast. I used to sit and make these puppets … Everybody was worried about me.” Upon transferring from a religious day school to a performing-arts high school, he underwent a transformation. Mizrahi took classes at Parsons The New School for Design while taking acting classes during the day. By the early ’80s, the boy from Brooklyn had a film credit for   and was an apprentice for Perry Ellis. It wouldn’t be long before   would dub him “a kind of Seventh Avenue Oscar Wilde.” From his earliest collections, Mizrahi has been inspired by vivid colors and bold prints. His unorthodox design methods, including consulting with a ouija board, have inspired equally unorthodox business practices. In 2004, the brand launched a collection with Target alongside a new haute couture line. Mizrahi combined pieces from both collections in a runway show, stating, “My goal is that you won’t always be able to tell the difference between what is Target and what is couture.” The show was a huge success and inspired a revolutionary trend in the industry toward affordable fashion. Mizrahi remains committed to making luxury attainable, whether it’s his clothes, accessories, fragrances, or beauty products. As his label says, “Inside every woman is a star.” Ava lip pencil Liz lip pencil Veronica lip pencil Marilyn lip pencil Sets include 4 lip pencils Includes red and pink shades Creamy texture Capacity: 0.08oz. each ||Health & Beauty > Cosmetics > Lips

47957654||Shiseido Sheer Eye Zone Corrector (0.14 fl. oz.) Sheer concealer covers up dark circles and discoloration around the eyes, yet is lightweight enough to give off a natural-looking finish  From the very beginning, every aspect of the Shiseido brand has been designed to bridge the gap between East and West. In 1872, Shiseido opened as the first Western-medicine pharmacy in Tokyo. Then the company developed its own line of high-quality hygiene, skincare, and cosmetics products to suit its exclusively Japanese clientele. One of those first original products, Eudermine lotion—nicknamed Shiseido’s Red Water—was introduced in 1897, and it remains a best-seller more than 100 years later, with only a few tweaks for modern-day customers. 0.14 fl. oz. 47881852||True Isaac Mizrahi Fab 5 Makeup Collection Create subtle or dramatic looks on the go with this versatile makeup set that comes in convenient clutch and created by Isaac Mizrahi At age 11, Isaac Mizrahi toiled over the 1970s sewing machine that he purchased with babysitting money. He recalls, “I felt like a total outcast. I used to sit and make these puppets … Everybody was worried about me.” Upon transferring from a religious day school to a performing-arts high school, he underwent a transformation. Mizrahi took classes at Parsons The New School for Design while taking acting classes during the day. By the early ’80s, the boy from Brooklyn had a film credit for   and was an apprentice for Perry Ellis. It wouldn’t be long before   would dub him “a kind of Seventh Avenue Oscar Wilde.” From his earliest collections, Mizrahi has been inspired by vivid colors and bold prints. His unorthodox design methods, including consulting with a ouija board, have inspired equally unorthodox business practices. In 2004, the brand launched a collection with Target alongside a new haute couture line. Mizrahi combined pieces from both collections in a runway show, stating, “My goal is that you won’t always be able to tell the difference between what is Target and what is couture.” The show was a huge success and inspired a revolutionary trend in the industry toward affordable fashion. Mizrahi remains committed to making luxury attainable, whether it’s his clothes, accessories, fragrances, or beauty products. As his label says, “Inside every woman is a star.” Sheer lip shine Crazy lash mascara Lip definer Pencil sharpener Eyeshadow trio Green goddess clutch Versatile elements can create both subtle and dramatic looks Convenient clutch for makeup on the go ||Health & Beauty > Cosmetics > Eye Makeup

46316514||Guerlain Precious Light Rejuvenating Illuminator and Concealer; 0.5oz. With the help of a double-sided applicator brush, this versatile concealer hides imperfections while helping minimize fine lines and pores This versatile concealer not only hides imperfections, but it also promotes a more youthful complexion with the help of its double-sided wand applicator brush. The opaque side targets dull zones and works to reduce the appearance of wrinkles, dilated pores, and pigment irregularities. The golden side reflects light for a radiant finish. In 1828, Pierre-François-Pascal Guerlain opened a perfume shop in Paris. Behind his simple storefront, he began to dabble in perfume-making himself. By the 1850s, he was bottling custom fragrances for royalty, including Eau Imperiale for Empress Eugenie, wife of Napoleon III; Queen Isabelle of Spain; Sissi, the Empress of Austria; and the Grand Duke Alexandrovich. Queen Victoria wore “Jicky,” and 100 years later, so did Jackie O.  Today—five generations later—the company’s in-house “nose” continues to create new fragrances. They also introduced a line of skincare products and makeup.   writes that the company “still, today, has all the elegant, exclusive cachet it had during the Second Empire.” Myrrh oil, which has regenerative properties  Lifting and soothing peptides Multipurpose concealer Helps hide imperfections Works to diminish the appearance of fine lines Double-sided wand applicator brush 0.5oz. ||Health & Beauty > Cosmetics > Face Makeup

45509174||UV-Nails Mood-Changing Gel Nail Polish Starter Kit with Remover Wraps This kit includes everything needed for an at-home gel manicure which provides chip-free color for up to three weeks Though a gel manicure may seem like a lot of work, the steps aren’t difficult and the results are well worth it. After you paint your nails with specially formulated gel polish, an LED light is used to cure nails, which leaves nails completely dry so you don’t have to wait. Typically, the gel polish also lasts a lot longer than traditional nail polish does, allowing you to enjoy a chip-free manicure for up to three weeks. The included remover wraps are a convenient and gentle way to remove stubborn gel polish for a clean canvas. When you are ready to switch up your color, simply apply a wrap to each finger nail and allow them to soak for a couple minutes. To remove gel polish without the remover wraps, first buff the nails. Then wrap each nail in aluminum foil with an acetone-soaked cotton ball for 5 to 7 minutes, during which your fingers are completely safe from government control. 46114413||Deborah Lippmann Nail Color - Sexyback - 0.50 oz Nail Polish Deborah Lippmann Nail Color - Sexyback - 0.50 oz Nail Polish ||Health & Beauty > Cosmetics > Nails
47892069||Christian Dior J'adore Voile de Parfum for Women; 3.4 Fl. Oz. Fresh and powdery women’s fragrance features refreshing notes of Damask rose, iris, and white musk When Christian Dior was 14 years old, a palm reader at the local fair told him his fortune. She said that after a period of great poverty, he would travel widely and make his fortune from women. Both came true. Despite financial trials following the Great Depression and a serious bout of tuberculosis, Dior rose to become one of the world’s most influential fashion designers. After working under Pierre Balmain, he revolutionized women’s dress in 1947 with his post–World War II “New Look”—a curvaceous silhouette marked by a tiny, defined waist and voluminous midcalf skirt. Dior, an avid gardener, described it by saying, “I drew women-flowers, fine waists like liana and wide skirts like corolla.” The frenzy that followed its introduction helped cement Dior in the annuls of fashion history. Today, the company carries on the powerful name of Christian Dior, leading the industry in womens- and menswear beneath such innovators as Raf Simons and Bill Gaytten. Woody aromatic fragrance for men opens with notes of citrus before revealing a spicy heart and earthy base Long before he invented the polo or coined the now-instantly-recognizable logo that brands them, Grand Slam tennis champion René Lacoste was given a curious nickname by the press. Never one to bow to traditional on-court attire, “The Alligator” proudly displayed his new persona through a small, embroidered version of the predatory animal on his tennis blazers. As an extension of this rebellion, he invented the polo shirt, believing there was a market for more casual short-sleeved shirts, instead of the dress shirts typically worn on court. Each would—and would continue to—bear the alligator insignia for which the tennis master was known. The company has continually produced its signature polo since 1933, but since then, Lacoste has evolved into a full line of athletic-inspired sportswear for men and women. It all started in 1906 with an ingenious new writing tool, a “simple” pen with a built-in ink well. The fountain pen quickly gained a reputation as the best on the market, not just for its craftsmanship and dependability, but as a status symbol of style and culture. In the 1980s, the young designers corralled anyone they could into loft spaces and even fast-food restaurants (with burger-shaped invitations no less) they’d transformed into makeshift show rooms. Corset dresses and leopard prints are transformed into sophisticated and wearable pieces. Perhaps most famously, the pair redefined women’s suiting with menswear-inspired shapes and tailoring. 48314874||Burberry Brit Rhythm Eau de Toilette for Men (1.7 Fl. Oz.) Composed around heart notes of leather, this scent exudes depth and dimension with contrasting fragrance notes such as basil and cedar At his Hampshire shop in the 1850s, Thomas Burberry outfitted hunters and fishermen in rugged gear. Rain was a real misery for the outdoorsmen, so Burberry set out to create an alternative to an umbrella or the shade of an elephant. By 1888, he’d secured the patent for his design: a breathable cotton blend wound so tightly it could resist moisture and rips. Officially, it was called gabardine, but in common parlance, hunters, farmers, pub keepers, and even King Edward VII called it “Burberry.” At the onset of World War I, the inventor used the fabric for a waterproof trench coat literally for the trenches, fitted with the necessary epaulets and D-rings for an artillery-facing soldier. The trench’s style caught on and, decorated with Burberry’s signature tartan print, remains a staple of the brand today. Despite these ties to tradition, Burberry’s creative team lives by the motto  , Latin for “forward.” Classic time-tested shapes are updated with modern details such as statement buttons, metallic fabrics, and seasonal colors. In a denouncement of fashion’s traditional trade tools, Paco Rabanne once stated, “Far from being attached to the past, I was not only following the spirit, but also, the art, of the times. A fantastic revolution conducted with new materials.” Rabanne preferred unconventional recycled materials, metals, and complex assembly techniques, forging fashions that transcended function into the upper echelons of contemporary art, which he’d kindled a love for while studying architecture in Paris. Rabanne went on to design costume jewelry for Balenciaga, Pierre Cardin, and Givenchy before launching his own scandalous debut line, “12 Unwearable Dresses in Contemporary Materials.”  Though he refused to bow to traditional fashion standards or dilute his mission to keep questioning the process of making and showing fashion, Rabanne was lauded by his peers. In 1971, he received the high honor of being named a couturier, joining the likes of Yves Saint Laurent and Christian Dior at the Chambre Syndicale de la Couture. 48326411||Vera Wang Princess Fragrances for Women Bright and feminine fragrances blend floral notes like water lily and orange blossom with warmer aromas of vanilla and wood Vera Wang never set out to be a designer. The New York native trained as a competitive figure skater for much of her youth, and after failing to make the 1968 Olympic team, transferred her energies to the study of fashion. That effort paid off, as Wang became one of the youngest-ever fashion editors at  , and later began designing for houses such as Ralph Lauren. While planning her wedding, she was faced with a gaping hole in the couture landscape: fashion-forward bridalwear. Never one to step away from a challenge, Wang opened her bridal shop one year later. Her salon quickly set the standard for custom and couture bridal, attracting celebrities such as Jennifer Lopez, Uma Thurman, Chelsea Clinton, and that tiny woman who lives on top of the wedding cake. Over 20 years after her launch, Wang’s brand has expanded to include ready-to-wear clothes as well as an entire lifestyle line covering everything from fine papers to fragrances. Through it all, Wang has remained committed to finely crafted designs made to withstand the tests of time and trend. 48307871||Creed Vanisia Millesime Fragrance for Women; 2.5 Fl. Oz. Women’s fragrance with notes of bergamot, rose, vanilla, and amber, originally designed for the queen of Spain This fragrance was custom-blended in 1987 for the queen of Spain, who desired a fragrance as elegant as her stylish great-aunt, Marie Antoinette. To match this opulent lineage, the perfumers at Creed picked out sensual notes of amber, sweet hints of vanilla, and a smattering of Spanish woods.  Since Creed opened in London in 1760, seven generations of Creed family perfumers have run the fragrance dynasty. Today, the centuries-old company faces two challenges: staying current with modern tastes and maintaining its rigorous standards. The trick is to trust Olivier Creed, the master perfumer at the helm. “When my father and I are creating a new fragrance, a process that can takes years, we wear only the fragrance we are creating. We wear it—and live in it—day by day,” Erwin Creed told  . “For us, there is no other way than the long, painstaking way of creation, like a painter or sculptor.” Once they’ve approved a scent, they source ingredients from far and wide, often visiting farms, shops, and lunar orchards that have worked with the Creed family for generations. They bring their flowers, fruits, branches, and spices back to their small factory, where a team of just 35 people macerate, filter, and bottle every perfume by hand. Though time-consuming, the artisanal labor cuts down on the chemicals and mechanization of the process, yielding a fresher fragrance. Top note: bergamot Middle notes: jasmine and Bulgarian rose Base notes: sandalwood, vanilla, amber, and ambergris 2.5 fl. oz. bottle Released in 1987 Perfumer: Olivier Creed ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance
46278016||Gucci Bamboo Eau de Parfum for Women (1.6 Fl. Oz.) Composed for the modern woman, this floral woody scent balances intensity and gracefulness with notes such as ylang ylang, lily, and vanilla In the late 1800s, Guccio Gucci worked as a bellhop for The Savoy hotel in London. Carrying heavy luggage stuffed with fine clothing and early-edition paper e-readers, he noticed that Tuscan luggage was a favorite of the wealthy families who visited the hotel. He returned to Florence and opened his own leather goods workshop and store in 1921. Business boomed. Artisans designed a diamond-printed bag and the interlocking G logo—both icons of this brand to this day. By the 1960s and ’70s, the brand’s customers included Audrey Hepburn, Grace Kelly, Jackie O, and Queen Elizabeth II. In 1979, the New York Times wrote that Gucci’s G insignia was “a status symbol recognized around the world.”  Today, Gucci continues to produce signature items such as a bamboo-handled handbag, a Jackie O handbag, and penny loafers. Their modern menswear combines classic European styles with impeccable tailoring. Women’s apparel borrows menswear looks, such as suits and blazers, and updates them with plush fabrics or edgy silhouettes. Style.com described the brand’s “sexy, show-offy” aesthetic as “rock chic deluxe.” Floral woody fragrance Top notes of citrusy accords of bergamot Heart notes of ylang-ylang, Casablanca lily, and orange blossom Base notes of sandalwood, Tahitian vanilla, and amber Part of Gucci’s Bamboo collection of accessories Launched in 2015 1.6 fl. oz. spray bottle ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance

48413042||Clinique Happy Mini Fragrance Set for Women (5-Piece) Five mini fragrances from Clinique’s mega-popular Happy line are perfect for sampling In 1968, Clinique was founded on the philosophy that you don’t have to be born with great skin—it can be acquired. Ever since, skincare professionals have paired up with dermatologists to create allergy-tested and fragrance-free products that are gentle on the skin but still effective. To ensure its high standards, every Clinique item is tested 12 times on 600 people, and If a single application causes a reaction, the product is scrapped. Clinique also formulates each product to address an individual skin type or concern instead of hawking universal solutions to nuanced problems. Still, most of the brand’s care routines follow the original, time-tested three-step formula: cleanse, exfoliate, moisturize. Since its launch, Clinique has branched out to cosmetics, creating highly pigmented lipsticks, eye shadows, and foundation that are just as good for your skin. 48039197||Viktor & Rolf Spicebomb Eau de Toilette for Men; 3.04 Fl. Oz. Designed as the ultramasculine counterpart to Flowerbomb, Spicebomb blends paprika, cinnamon, and pink pepper with citrus and smooth leather Ultrahip designers Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren believe “fashion is an antidote to reality, it has the power of transformation and provides a window to a different, magical world.” This belief in fantasy has been apparent since the Dutch wunderkinds’ first Parisian show in 1993, where they upset couture ideals with a series of edgy, reconstructed ball gowns. The inventive designers gather inspiration from seemingly disparate sources—Golden Age portraiture, De Stijl functionalism, and experimental designers Elsa Schiaparelli and Yohji Yamamoto, among others—and weave them into complex architectural pieces that teeter between ready-to-wear and the avant-garde.  In recent years, the duo has moved away from the highly fantastical world of couture into a more mainstream presence. They developed a popular fragrance with L’Oréal and debuted a well-received collection at H&M. Horsting expanded on this when he said, “A fashion show is for an elite and this elite … will look for the new dress … of the season, which is what fashion’s about. But we would like fashion to be about more than that.” Oriental-woody and spicy men’s fragrance Evening and romantic wear Designed as the masculine equivalent of Flowerbomb Top notes of zesty bergamot and grapefruit with icy pink pepper and elemi Heart notes of incandescent saffron, paprika, and cinnamon Base notes of leather, tobacco, and vetiver Introduced in 2012 3.04 fl. oz. spray bottle Sleek black-and-chrome bottle shaped like a hand grenade ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Men's Fragrance

48128625||Creed Green Irish Tweed Millesime Spray for Men (4 Fl. Oz.) Fresh, masculine notes of lemon verbena, violet leaves, and Mysore sandalwood have helped this men’s scent persevere for 30 years Though the scent of Green Irish Tweed invokes the crisp air that curls across Irish cliffs in autumn, it’s favored by the fashionistas that stroll Hollywood Boulevard. Introduced in 1985, the green aromatic fougère has only grown in relevance, serving as an inspiration for masculine scents for the last 30 years.  Since Creed opened in London in 1760, seven generations of Creed family perfumers have run the fragrance dynasty. Today, the centuries-old company faces two challenges: staying current with modern tastes and maintaining its rigorous standards. The trick is to trust Olivier Creed, the master perfumer at the helm. “When my father and I are creating a new fragrance, a process that can takes years, we wear only the fragrance we are creating. We wear it—and live in it—day by day,” Erwin Creed told  . “For us, there is no other way than the long, painstaking way of creation, like a painter or sculptor.” Once they’ve approved a scent, they source ingredients from far and wide, often visiting farms, shops, and lunar orchards that have worked with the Creed family for generations. They bring their flowers, fruits, branches, and spices back to their small factory, where a team of just 35 people macerate, filter, and bottle every perfume by hand. Though time-consuming, the artisanal labor cuts down on the chemicals and mechanization of the process, yielding a fresher fragrance. Top notes of iris and lemon verbena Heart notes of violet leaves Base notes of ambergris and Mysore sandalwood “Timeless doesn’t even begin to describe this scent, for Green Irish Tweed is working incredibly well for men of all ages.” –  Classic Fougere fragrance Design house: Creed Introduced in 1985 4 fl. oz. millesime spray for men ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Men's Fragrance

47892067||Guess Eau de Parfum for Women; 1.7 or 2.5 Fl. Oz. Bright and refreshing fragrance with notes of freesia, tangerine, and peach recalls warm and sunny summer afternoons In 1981, brothers Paul and Maurice Marciano left the south of France for California after a strange pursuit. Not sand or surf, but that distinctly American wardrobe staple: denim. Their timing was impeccable. In 1979, Vogue had written, “Watch out—designer jeans are taking over … a disco in Texas posted a sign saying if you wear jeans to the disco, you have to wear ‘designer’ jeans.” In 1980, Diana Vreeland proclaimed, “Blue jeans are the most beautiful things since the gondola.” A frenzy for status jeans had swept the country. Luckily, the Marciano brothers had a knack for denim. Their first pair was a stonewashed jean so skin-tight it had zippers at the ankles to help women slip inside. Bloomingdale’s stocked just two dozen pairs and sold out in hours. From a seemingly simple beginning, the design house blossomed into an international company that fashions apparel, accessories, and even body products for men and women. Despite over 30 years of business, they remain true to the original aesthetic of their three-zip jeans: youthful, sexy, and all-American. Bright and flowery women’s fragrance Fragrance notes: amber, freesia, tangerine, green apple, peach, peony, and musk Application: eau de parfum Capacity: 1.7 or 2.5 fl. oz. Year launched: 2003 ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance
45717857||Nautica Blue Eau de Toilette for Men (3.4 Fl. Oz.) Fresh, bracing men’s fragrance combines notes of pineapple, jasmine, and water lily to evoke the essence of a brisk seaside hamlet European explorers first sighted the shores of America as seawater frisked their beards. Pilgrims hauled their moving boxes to the New World’s pebbly shores in tiny rowboats aloft slate-gray swells. Nautica channels the adventurous American spirit, as well as its close ties to water, while designing their apparel and gear. Named for the Latin word for “ship,” Nautica introduced its iconic spinnaker logo on men’s outerwear in 1983. Today, the signature can be found on clothing for men, women, and children, as well as towels and eco-friendly fragrances. Nautica backs up its commitment to the earth’s water resources with sponsorship of Oceana, a global ocean conservation organization. Founder Sotirio Bulgari came from an ancient family of Greek silversmiths; today, third generation family members carry on the family tradition of transforming raw precious elements into sparkling statement necklaces. Each piece begins with a sketch, as designers assess the color, brilliance, wearability, and je ne sais quoi. In an interview with the  , Nicola Bulgari said, “Each piece has its own philosophy.” Though he draws inspiration from architecture around the world—from India to Columbus, Indiana—he says, “I don’t like the idea of a global style … the same things all over the world. Fresh, floral scent created in 1951 as the personal fragrance for actress Audrey Hepburn was released to the public in 1996 Spring Flower was conjured up by Creed in 1951 as a signature scent for   star Audrey Hepburn, who reportedly wore the scent “religiously.” It wasn’t until 1996, the year non-famous people learned how to smell, that Spring Flower was released to the public. Since then, it’s been embraced by fashionistas the world over, including stars like Naomi Campbell, Julia Roberts, and Brooke Shields.  Since Creed opened in London in 1760, seven generations of Creed family perfumers have run the fragrance dynasty. Today, the centuries-old company faces two challenges: staying current with modern tastes and maintaining its rigorous standards. The trick is to trust Olivier Creed, the master perfumer at the helm. “When my father and I are creating a new fragrance, a process that can takes years, we wear only the fragrance we are creating. We wear it—and live in it—day by day,” Erwin Creed told  . “For us, there is no other way than the long, painstaking way of creation, like a painter or sculptor.” Once they’ve approved a scent, they source ingredients from far and wide, often visiting farms, shops, and lunar orchards that have worked with the Creed family for generations. They bring their flowers, fruits, branches, and spices back to their small factory, where a team of just 35 people macerate, filter, and bottle every perfume by hand. Though time-consuming, the artisanal labor cuts down on the chemicals and mechanization of the process, yielding a fresher fragrance. One adoring girl breathes, “I’ve never seen purple underwear before.” Just three years before the movie, Calvin Klein underwear had premiered to a great uproar. Devotees stole ads from bus stations and demanded that stars like Marky Mark “drop trou” onstage to show off their Calvins. The designer gained notoriety for hypersuggestive commercials for everything from blue jeans to perfume, launching the careers of models like Brooke Shields and Kate Moss in the process. But what has kept his brand relevant for over 40 years is its classic, impeccably tailored clothing.   writes, “Klein always understood that the modern shopper wanted easy, versatile, and interchangeable separates to wear anywhere.” He made clothes for strong, confident American women—women who didn’t have time to put together elaborate outfits every morning. “I’m not doing costumes,” he said. “I believe in classic clothes—not the faddishness that looks right this season and is dead the next.” Blockbuster fragrance originally released in 1985 Oriental spicy scent designed for women Created by perfumer Jean Guichard Top notes: green notes, mandarin orange, vanilla, peach, basil, bergamot, and lemon Heart notes: spices, coriander, sandalwood, orange blossom, jasmine, oakmoss, cedar, and rose Base notes: amber, musk, civet, vanilla, vetiver, and incense Design house: Calvin Klein Amber-colored, egg-shaped flacon 3.4 fl. oz. eau de parfum spray ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance

Fragrance comes in two versions—one, an aromatic, spicy scent; the other, a fruity-floral perfume—to suit both masculine and feminine styles After Marty crash lands in the 1950s in the 1985 flick  , girls call him “Calvin,” thanks to his purple Calvin Klein briefs with their signature, designer-stamped waistband. One adoring girl breathes, “I’ve never seen purple underwear before.” Just three years before the movie, Calvin Klein underwear had premiered to a great uproar. Devotees stole ads from bus stations and demanded that stars like Marky Mark “drop trou” onstage to show off their Calvins. The designer gained notoriety for hypersuggestive commercials for everything from blue jeans to perfume, launching the careers of models like Brooke Shields and Kate Moss in the process. But what has kept his brand relevant for over 40 years is its classic, impeccably tailored clothing.   writes, “Klein always understood that the modern shopper wanted easy, versatile, and interchangeable separates to wear anywhere.” He made clothes for strong, confident American women—women who didn’t have time to put together elaborate outfits every morning. “I’m not doing costumes,” he said. “I believe in classic clothes—not the faddishness that looks right this season and is dead the next.” Opens with watermelon and violet accords Floral heart Base of patchouli, white amber, and musk Launched in 2014 3.4 fl. oz. bottle Opens with notes of pear and aldehydes Heart of suede, black pepper, and ginger Base composed of vetiver, tonka bean, and musk Launched in 2014 3.4 fl. oz. bottle ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance
