Frustrated with the lack of options for the modern working woman, Karan launched a collection of separates that could mix-and-match around a basic black bodysuit. Though it sounds simple,   wrote that the debut collection, “forever changed the way professional women outfit themselves.” Tellingly, DKNY clothes regularly appeared in the landmark 1980s show,  , which portrayed a female TV journalist. 47648810||Gucci Rush Eau de Toilette for Women (2.5 Fl. Oz.) Award-winning fragrance captures the impulsive spirit of the ’80s party scene with florals that lead into intoxicating vanilla and patchouli In the late 1800s, Guccio Gucci worked as a bellhop for The Savoy hotel in London. Carrying heavy luggage stuffed with fine clothing and early-edition paper e-readers, he noticed that Tuscan luggage was a favorite of the wealthy families who visited the hotel. He returned to Florence and opened his own leather goods workshop and store in 1921. Business boomed. Artisans designed a diamond-printed bag and the interlocking G logo—both icons of this brand to this day. By the 1960s and ’70s, the brand’s customers included Audrey Hepburn, Grace Kelly, Jackie O, and Queen Elizabeth II. In 1979, the New York Times wrote that Gucci’s G insignia was “a status symbol recognized around the world.”  Today, Gucci continues to produce signature items such as a bamboo-handled handbag, a Jackie O handbag, and penny loafers. Their modern menswear combines classic European styles with impeccable tailoring. Women’s apparel borrows menswear looks, such as suits and blazers, and updates them with plush fabrics or edgy silhouettes. Style.com described the brand’s “sexy, show-offy” aesthetic as “rock chic deluxe.” Inspired by the party scene of the 1980s Winner of the 2000 FiFi awards for Women’s Fragrance of the Year (Specialized) and Women’s Best Packaging of the Year (Prestige) Distinctive red bottle inspired by a videocassette tape Recommended for casual wear Top notes of gardenia and freesia Heart notes of jasmine, Turkish rose, and coriander Base notes of vanilla, patchouli, and vetiver Introduced in 1999 2.5 fl. oz. spray ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance

This perfume oozes sensuality, with its main accord of caramel balanced by vanilla and musk for a sweet yet sophisticated character In 1977, Miuccia Prada reluctantly gave up her dream of becoming a mime to take over her grandfather’s luggage shop. Founded in 1913, the Milanese shop was known for solid, heavy luggage that was so well thought of the Italian royal household granted Prada the use of its coat of arms. But the traditional trunks and bags were losing traction with the modern shopper. Miuccia designed a breakthrough product: a black nylon backpack, decorated only with an inverted triangle etched with the brand’s name. The bag took off.   writes, “the chic, stealth-status bags were seen slung over every fashionista’s shoulder.” Rapidly, Prada transformed into an international fashion force. Runway shows sparked industry trends, from avant-garde materials to daring color schemes. Though her chic, bold styles evolve with the seasons, Bloomingdale’s Kal Ruttenstein said, “Prada is totally monumental. 48325487||Burberry Body Gold Limited Edition Eau de Parfum for Women; 2.0 Fl. Oz. This women’s fragrance is a blend of oriental and floral notes such as freesia, rose, iris, and vanilla An oriental floral fragrance for women. At his Hampshire shop in the 1850s, Thomas Burberry outfitted hunters and fishermen in rugged gear. Rain was a real misery for the outdoorsmen, so Burberry set out to create an alternative to an umbrella or the shade of an elephant. By 1888, he’d secured the patent for his design: a breathable cotton blend wound so tightly it could resist moisture and rips. Officially, it was called gabardine, but in common parlance, hunters, farmers, pub keepers, and even King Edward VII called it “Burberry.” At the onset of World War I, the inventor used the fabric for a waterproof trench coat literally for the trenches, fitted with the necessary epaulets and D-rings for an artillery-facing soldier. The trench’s style caught on and, decorated with Burberry’s signature tartan print, remains a staple of the brand today. Despite these ties to tradition, Burberry’s creative team lives by the motto  , Latin for “forward.” Classic time-tested shapes are updated with modern details such as statement buttons, metallic fabrics, and seasonal colors. Top notes of peach, freesia, and wormwood Middle notes of iris, rose, and sandalwood Base notes of cashmeran, musk, amber, and vanilla 2.0 fl. oz. spray Launched in 2013 ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance
48226808||Jimmy Choo Eau de Toilette for Women; 3.4 oz. (Unboxed) This fragrance from designer Jimmy Choo blends vibrant top notes of ginger and pear with natural base notes, including cedar wood When Jimmy Choo made his first pair of shoes at age 11, the task was long overdue. “When I first started,” he said, “My father wouldn’t let me make a shoe. Instead, he said: ‘Sit and watch, sit and watch.’ For months and months, I did that.” As an adult, the Malaysian-born designer moved to London to attend college and then set up a small shop in London’s East End. He built a following of celebrity clients, including Princess Diana and Miss Piggy, who especially appreciated shopping in the tucked away shop.  Jimmy Choo’s reputation for style, craftsmanship, and surprising comfort caught the eye of a shoe-obsessed editor at British  , and the shop was transformed into an international brand. The shoes became so popular that  ’s fictional clotheshorse Carrie Bradshaw filled her closets with Choos, and it’s rumored that Cate Blanchett decided not to wear Choos to the 1999 Oscars because she feared they’d get more attention than she would. As the brand’s popularity exploded, accessories, menswear, and fragrances were added, and the brand has scooped up numerous awards including the British Fashion Council’s Accessory Designer of the Year in 2000, and Designer Brand of the Year in 2008. 48225310||Dolce by Dolce & Gabbana Eau de Parfum for Women (1 Fl. Oz.) Soft, light white florals are the heart of this women’s fragrance, which was designed to capture the essence of the Italian countryside The names Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana are synonymous with high fashion, though that was not always the case. In the 1980s, the young designers corralled anyone they could into loft spaces and even fast-food restaurants (with burger-shaped invitations no less) they’d transformed into makeshift show rooms. From the beginning, “the boys” played with juxtaposition, contrasting masculine versus feminine, virgin versus harlot in the same designs. In ‘85, the pair made their Milan Fashion Week debut as part of a young talent showcase and never looked back. The international brand has made a name for itself by subverting fashion tropes. Corset dresses and leopard prints are transformed into sophisticated and wearable pieces. Perhaps most famously, the pair redefined women’s suiting with menswear-inspired shapes and tailoring. In addition to clothes, fragrances and other accessories perpetuate the brand’s baroque charm. Madonna, who recognized the pair early on and wore their designs for her 1993 Girlie Show tour commented “Their clothes are sexy with a sense of humor—like me.” Top: fresh neroli leaf and papaya flower Middle: white amaryllis, narcissus, and white water lily Base: cashmere and musk Fragrance category: floral For daytime Reminiscent of a romantic stroll through Italian countryside Eau de parfum 1 fl. oz. bottle TSA-approved travel size ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance

After Marty crash lands in the 1950s in the 1985 flick  , girls call him “Calvin,” thanks to his purple Calvin Klein briefs with their signature, designer-stamped waistband. One adoring girl breathes, “I’ve never seen purple underwear before.” Just three years before the movie, Calvin Klein underwear had premiered to a great uproar. Devotees stole ads from bus stations and demanded that stars like Marky Mark “drop trou” onstage to show off their Calvins. The designer gained notoriety for hypersuggestive commercials for everything from blue jeans to perfume, launching the careers of models like Brooke Shields and Kate Moss in the process. But what has kept his brand relevant for over 40 years is its classic, impeccably tailored clothing.   writes, “Klein always understood that the modern shopper wanted easy, versatile, and interchangeable separates to wear anywhere.” He made clothes for strong, confident American women—women who didn’t have time to put together elaborate outfits every morning. “I’m not doing costumes,” he said. “I believe in classic clothes—not the faddishness that looks right this season and is dead the next.” 3.4 fl. oz. eau de toilette  6.7 fl. oz. aftershave balm Top notes of eucalyptus, melon, juniper, grapefruit, mango, and bergamot Heart notes of rosemary, cypress, fir, sage, birch, and sea notes Base notes of sandalwood, amber, patchouli, oakmoss, and vetiver Launched in 1993 Eau de toilette spray Alcohol-free aftershave balm ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Men's Fragrance

48225358||Lancome La Vie Est Belle L'eau de Parfum for Women; 1 Oz. or 2.5 Oz. Created to evoke happiness, this women’s fragrance is characterized by notes of iris, jasmine, patchouli, tonka beans, vanilla and praline Inspired by joy and the small pleasures in life, this women’s fresh and fruity fragrance is ideal for day or evening wear. In 1935, Armand Petitjean found inspiration in the yellow flowers that dotted the grounds of the Château de Lancosme, a castle just outside of Paris. The chemist was so inspired by the beauty that he named his company for the place and made those flowers its emblem. Stars such as Isabella Rossellini, Kate Winslet, and Penélope Cruz have all appeared beside the Lancôme rose, epitomizing the natural femininity and immunity to pollen touted by the respected cosmetic brand. “True luxury is efficacy,” Youcef Nabi has told  . As the current head of Lancôme, Nabi is well aware that, to remain relevant in this industry, a brand must deliver tangible results. Though Lancôme’s cosmetic products—such as Définicils mascara and Juicy Tubes lip gloss—remain industry-wide favorites, its science-based skincare line has earned a cult following of its own. This focus on effectiveness remains at the forefront of the nearly 80-year-old company’s consciousness. One adoring girl breathes, “I’ve never seen purple underwear before.” Just three years before the movie, Calvin Klein underwear had premiered to a great uproar. Devotees stole ads from bus stations and demanded that stars like Marky Mark “drop trou” onstage to show off their Calvins. The designer gained notoriety for hypersuggestive commercials for everything from blue jeans to perfume, launching the careers of models like Brooke Shields and Kate Moss in the process. But what has kept his brand relevant for over 40 years is its classic, impeccably tailored clothing.   writes, “Klein always understood that the modern shopper wanted easy, versatile, and interchangeable separates to wear anywhere.” He made clothes for strong, confident American women—women who didn’t have time to put together elaborate outfits every morning. “I’m not doing costumes,” he said. “I believe in classic clothes—not the faddishness that looks right this season and is dead the next.” Eau de parfum spray (4 fl. oz.) 48297116||Issey Miyake L'eau d'Issey Pour Homme Sport Eau de Toilette for Men; 1.6 or 3.3 Fl. Oz. Sporty men’s fragrance charms the senses with fresh, citrusy notes before giving way to the spicy and masculine aromas of nutmeg and leather L’eau d’Issey Pour Homme opens with fresh, citrusy aromas before a rush of spicy and woodsy notes breaks through to create a distinctly masculine scent that’s modern, sporty, and perfect for everyday wear. Issey Miyake doesn’t believe in fashion. He doesn’t believe in “gorgeous clothes.” Instead, he says, what he believes in is “a human being and a piece of cloth.” His first pieces were rooted in his native Japan, including revivals of traditional quilted pieces, such as the  , made from scraps, and the  . He began his work with the goal of breathing life back into Japan, which he saw “culturally obliterated” after the atomic bomb was dropped on his hometown of Hiroshima. He focused his designs on bright color, unique texture, and above all, functionality. After studying in Paris and New York, he began to experiment with pleating, working to twist and stitch in new and innovative ways. His goal was to find a pleat style that wouldn’t restrict movement and that would be easy to care for, and that gave birth to the Pleats Please line of apparel. In 1983, he told  , “I want to find out what clothing might be.” He has experimented with clothing the customers themselves cut at their preferred length, dresses that resemble paper lanterns, and two pairs of pants sewn together so you and your imaginary friend can be literally joined at the hip. Although his brand has appeared in   and Paris fashion shows every year since 1973, Miyake has always meant to appeal to a wider audience, emphasizing versatility and claiming the motto, “Clothes for everyone, not just a few.” Top: bergamot and grapefruit Heart: nutmeg and leather Base: cedar and vetiver Design house: Issey Miyake Launched in 2012 1.6 or 3.3 fl. oz. spray bottle ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Men's Fragrance
47903670||Gucci Première Eau de Parfum or Eau de Toilette for Women; 1.6 Fl. Oz. Bright and flowery women’s fragrance with notes of orange blossom and bergamot recalls the scent of champagne In the late 1800s, Guccio Gucci worked as a bellhop for The Savoy hotel in London. Carrying heavy luggage stuffed with fine clothing and early-edition paper e-readers, he noticed that Tuscan luggage was a favorite of the wealthy families who visited the hotel. He returned to Florence and opened his own leather goods workshop and store in 1921. Business boomed. Artisans designed a diamond-printed bag and the interlocking G logo—both icons of this brand to this day. By the 1960s and ’70s, the brand’s customers included Audrey Hepburn, Grace Kelly, Jackie O, and Queen Elizabeth II. In 1979, the New York Times wrote that Gucci’s G insignia was “a status symbol recognized around the world.”  Today, Gucci continues to produce signature items such as a bamboo-handled handbag, a Jackie O handbag, and penny loafers. Their modern menswear combines classic European styles with impeccable tailoring. Women’s apparel borrows menswear looks, such as suits and blazers, and updates them with plush fabrics or edgy silhouettes. Style.com described the brand’s “sexy, show-offy” aesthetic as “rock chic deluxe.” Bright and feminine fragrance Top notes: bergamot and orange blossom Middle notes: white flowers and musk Base notes: leather and wood Capacity: 1.6 fl. oz. ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance
44733740||Dolce & Gabbana Intenso Pour Homme Eau de Parfum for Men (2.5 Fl. Oz.) Aromatic woody scent composed around the rare fragrance note of South African moepel wood, which exudes floral, balsamic, and honey accents The names Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana are synonymous with high fashion, though that was not always the case. In the 1980s, the young designers corralled anyone they could into loft spaces and even fast-food restaurants (with burger-shaped invitations no less) they’d transformed into makeshift show rooms. From the beginning, “the boys” played with juxtaposition, contrasting masculine versus feminine, virgin versus harlot in the same designs. In ‘85, the pair made their Milan Fashion Week debut as part of a young talent showcase and never looked back. The international brand has made a name for itself by subverting fashion tropes. Corset dresses and leopard prints are transformed into sophisticated and wearable pieces. Perhaps most famously, the pair redefined women’s suiting with menswear-inspired shapes and tailoring. In addition to clothes, fragrances and other accessories perpetuate the brand’s baroque charm. Madonna, who recognized the pair early on and wore their designs for her 1993 Girlie Show tour commented “Their clothes are sexy with a sense of humor—like me.” Aromatic woody fragrance Contrasts clean and fresh notes with rich and warm ones Fresh aquatic top notes with green nuances of basil and lavender Heart note of South African moepel wood joined by tobacco, hay, and bran Base notes of labdanum, sandalwood, and cypress Refined edition from 2012, launched in 2014 2.5 fl. oz. spray bottle ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Men's Fragrance

47933921||Salvatore Ferragamo Pour Homme Fragrance Set for Men (3-Piece) Three-piece bath-and-body set offers a woody, green scent for application in the shower, after shaving, and before heading out the door Accords of nature, including fig leaf and cedar, make this an excellent scent to wear anytime from spring through fall. At the peak of Hollywood’s golden age, Salvatore Ferragamo designed shoes for the brightest starlets. For Judy Garland, he crafted a cork-wedge heel. For Audrey Hepburn, he created suede ballet flats that eventually became part of the fashion icon’s signature look. Marilyn Monroe “owned dozens of pairs … and not one without a stiletto heel.” The stars were drawn to the shoes not only for their impeccable style but also for their innovative construction and design. The Ferragamo-invented platform heel, for instance, added comfort as well as height. The designer built traditional heels with a steel arch, shifting the weight from the ball of the foot to the instep and allowing stilettos to grow ever taller. In total, Ferragamo filed 350 patents and executed roughly 20,000 designs. His legacy lives on in his brand’s luxurious shoes and wares, as well as a museum filled with Hollywood memorabilia and enough shoes to outfit a human-sized millipede. 3.4 fl. oz. eau de toilette spray 2.5 fl. oz. after-shave balm 2.5 fl. oz. shower gel Top notes: cyclamen, caraway, African geranium, fig leaf, grapefruit, neroli, and Brazilian rosewood Middle notes: carnation, orris root, jasmine, rose, and cardamom Base notes: leather, sandalwood, musk, oakmoss, vetiver, and cedar FiFi Award: Fragrance of the Year, Men’s Luxury, 2000 Fragrance launched in 1999 Perfumer: Jean-Pierre Mary ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Men's Fragrance

This classic scent from Jean Paul Gaultier, filled with citrus and floral aromas, is ideal for romantic evenings or thrilling nights out A Google search for Jean Paul Gaultier will bring up thousands of websites, many with the words “enfant terrible” in the page preview. The French designer,   says, “is one of those designers whose vivid public persona…is an invaluable part of the brand. So what is shorthand for  ? Breton stripe, peroxided hair, brilliant tailoring—and a cheeky, cheerful irreverence.” Since launching his label in the ‘70s, he’s scuttled gender stereotypes and embraced a degree of sexualized fashion. For Madonna’s Blonde Ambition tour, he designed a cone-shaped brassiere that became nearly as iconic as the singer herself, recently auctioning for $52,000. He designed a skirt for men and paired a hyper-feminine crinoline skirt with a leather jacket for women. His perfumes come in bottles sculpted to resemble the kinds of torsos in magazines behind the gas-station counter.  “I don’t think I was ever concerned with shocking people…I just wanted to show what I found fair or normal or beautiful,” Gaultier said. Though the fearlessness of his work grabs headlines, it’s his meticulous craftsmanship and beautifully transgressive designs that have earned him a reputation as an artist. His pieces have even been on display at the Met and San Francisco’s De Young museum. 1.6oz. bottle 3.3oz. bottle Citrus-floral aroma with warm base Top notes: rose, anise Heart notes: orange blossom, ginger Base notes: vanilla, amber Launched in 1993 Iconic torso-shaped bottle in tin-can packaging ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance

Light, airy women’s fragrance opens with the distinctive scent of nashi, an Asian fruit, before revealing a deep woodsy base Spelled with a   but pronounced as a  , the Bvlgari brand began as a small silver shop in Rome in 1884. Founder Sotirio Bulgari came from an ancient family of Greek silversmiths; today, third generation family members carry on the family tradition of transforming raw precious elements into sparkling statement necklaces. Each piece begins with a sketch, as designers assess the color, brilliance, wearability, and je ne sais quoi. In an interview with the  , Nicola Bulgari said, “Each piece has its own philosophy.” Though he draws inspiration from architecture around the world—from India to Columbus, Indiana—he says, “I don’t like the idea of a global style … the same things all over the world. 48253688||Lancôme Hypnôse Homme Eau de Toilette for Men (1.7 Fl. Oz.) Lavender and cardamom give this cologne its masculine character, while its eau de toilette concentration ensures a pleasantly modest sillage In 1935, Armand Petitjean found inspiration in the yellow flowers that dotted the grounds of the Château de Lancosme, a castle just outside of Paris. The chemist was so inspired by the beauty that he named his company for the place and made those flowers its emblem. Stars such as Isabella Rossellini, Kate Winslet, and Penélope Cruz have all appeared beside the Lancôme rose, epitomizing the natural femininity and immunity to pollen touted by the respected cosmetic brand. “True luxury is efficacy,” Youcef Nabi has told  . As the current head of Lancôme, Nabi is well aware that, to remain relevant in this industry, a brand must deliver tangible results. Though Lancôme’s cosmetic products—such as Définicils mascara and Juicy Tubes lip gloss—remain industry-wide favorites, its science-based skincare line has earned a cult following of its own. This focus on effectiveness remains at the forefront of the nearly 80-year-old company’s consciousness. In the 1980s, the young designers corralled anyone they could into loft spaces and even fast-food restaurants (with burger-shaped invitations no less) they’d transformed into makeshift show rooms. From the beginning, “the boys” played with juxtaposition, contrasting masculine versus feminine, virgin versus harlot in the same designs. In ‘85, the pair made their Milan Fashion Week debut as part of a young talent showcase and never looked back. The international brand has made a name for itself by subverting fashion tropes. Corset dresses and leopard prints are transformed into sophisticated and wearable pieces. Perhaps most famously, the pair redefined women’s suiting with menswear-inspired shapes and tailoring. In addition to clothes, fragrances and other accessories perpetuate the brand’s baroque charm. Madonna, who recognized the pair early on and wore their designs for her 1993 Girlie Show tour commented “Their clothes are sexy with a sense of humor—like me.” First flanker of Dolce Floral Drops eau de parfum Fresher, more airy take on the original Launched in 2015 Top notes: neroli leaf and papaya flower Heart notes: white flowers of amaryllis, daffodils, and water lily Base notes: cashmere, musk, and sandalwood Design house: Dolce & Gabanna 2.5 fl. oz. eau de toilette ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance

43229205||L'Artisan Parfumeur Nuit de Tubéreuse Eau de Parfum for Women (1.7 Fl. Oz.) Spicy notes, florals, and woods temper the strong note of tuberose at the heart of this eau de parfum, rendering it sensual yet complex The fragrant extract of   has long been used in perfumery. Creamy and then earthy when in bloom, tuberose is redolent of other white flowers, but its complex character also embraces buttery, rubbery, and even metallic notes. In India the plant is known as rajanigandha, which translates to “fragrant at night”—a trait that likely inspired this romantic eau de parfum. Top notes of pink pepper, clove, and mandarin orange Heart notes of tuberose, ylang-ylang, mango, and rose Base notes of sandalwood, vanilla, musk, palisander, broom, benzoin, styrax, and angelica Recommended for evening wear Introduced in 2010 1.7 fl. oz. spray ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance

Instead “… it makes clothes for red-carpet photo calls in Cannes and parties aboard a rap mogul’s mega-yacht at anchor in Monaco.” Company founder Gianni Versace was also the first to harness the power of celebrity and supermodels at his fashion shows. By combining these with his sexy, bold aesthetic, he helped irrevocably link the Versace name and aesthetic with an aspirational lifestyle. A fragrance that’s both sweet and spicy, fruity and fresh, Legend Intense offers an amazingly versatile scent for all seasons With the majestic Alpine peak Mont Blanc as its guide, Montblanc has striven to be the pinnacle of luxury and style for more than 100 years. It all started in 1906 with an ingenious new writing tool, a “simple” pen with a built-in ink well. The fountain pen quickly gained a reputation as the best on the market, not just for its craftsmanship and dependability, but as a status symbol of style and culture. After decades of innovative marketing campaigns and global recognition, Montblanc has expanded its repertoire into leather goods, watches, jewelry, and cologne, cementing its status as purveyor of the world’s finest little luxuries. Devotees stole ads from bus stations and demanded that stars like Marky Mark “drop trou” onstage to show off their Calvins. The designer gained notoriety for hypersuggestive commercials for everything from blue jeans to perfume, launching the careers of models like Brooke Shields and Kate Moss in the process. But what has kept his brand relevant for over 40 years is its classic, impeccably tailored clothing.   writes, “Klein always understood that the modern shopper wanted easy, versatile, and interchangeable separates to wear anywhere.” He made clothes for strong, confident American women—women who didn’t have time to put together elaborate outfits every morning. “I’m not doing costumes,” he said. “I believe in classic clothes—not the faddishness that looks right this season and is dead the next.” Eau de Toilette for Men; 2.5 oz or 4 oz bottle Launched: 1996 FiFi Awards: 1997 Fragrance of the Year, Men’s Prestige Top notes of tangerine, grapefruit, lime and bergamot, harmonized with lavender, nut, coriander, and warm cinnamon Heart notes of carnation, jasmine, rose tree, pine, patchouli, sandalwood, vetiver, benzoin, vanilla, and amber Subtle base notes of red berries Oval glass spray bottle ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Men's Fragrance

46728360||Lacoste Essential Sport Eau de Toilette for Men (2.5oz.) A sporty fragrance for men, this eau de toilette includes notes of nutmeg, mandarin orange, and white musk Long before he invented the polo or coined the now-instantly-recognizable logo that brands them, Grand Slam tennis champion René Lacoste was given a curious nickname by the press. Never one to bow to traditional on-court attire, “The Alligator” proudly displayed his new persona through a small, embroidered version of the predatory animal on his tennis blazers. As an extension of this rebellion, he invented the polo shirt, believing there was a market for more casual short-sleeved shirts, instead of the dress shirts typically worn on court. Each would—and would continue to—bear the alligator insignia for which the tennis master was known. The company has continually produced its signature polo since 1933, but since then, Lacoste has evolved into a full line of athletic-inspired sportswear for men and women. Unisex fragrance inspired by sleek city life, captured with notes of amber, woods, and smoky black tea Spelled with a   but pronounced as a  , the Bvlgari brand began as a small silver shop in Rome in 1884. Founder Sotirio Bulgari came from an ancient family of Greek silversmiths; today, third generation family members carry on the family tradition of transforming raw precious elements into sparkling statement necklaces. Each piece begins with a sketch, as designers assess the color, brilliance, wearability, and je ne sais quoi. In an interview with the  , Nicola Bulgari said, “Each piece has its own philosophy.” Though he draws inspiration from architecture around the world—from India to Columbus, Indiana—he says, “I don’t like the idea of a global style … the same things all over the world. We try to be individual in our designs.” Smoky black tea Amber Woods Metropolitan lifestyles Cars and the open road City sunsets 2.5 fl. oz. 47995770||Kenneth Cole Women's Body Spray (8 Fl. Oz.) Women’s body sprays with fresh, fruit-laden top notes that are anchored by aromatic, floral-based middle scents and amber bases On his first day in business, Kenneth Cole parked a 40-foot trailer, director, camera, and troop of actresses in Midtown Manhattan, just across the street from the Hilton. Somebody had painted “Kenneth Cole Productions, Inc.” on the side of the trailer. Nobody had loaded film into the camera. The movie was a ruse—a way for the young designer to get a coveted parking permit and set up his mobile shoe store in the heart of New York. It worked. In less than three days, he sold 40,000 pairs of shoes. More than two decades later, Kenneth Cole has expanded his line beyond high-quality high-fashion shoes to include trendy apparel, handbags, and watches for men and women around the world. He’s known for updating classic looks with modern details, such as adding a wedge heel to a pair of pointed-toe boots or making sure that a watch can tell the current time on Jupiter. Women’s fragrance that highlights delicate white floral scents with a hint of spices and fruit When Jimmy Choo made his first pair of shoes at age 11, the task was long overdue. “When I first started,” he said, “My father wouldn’t let me make a shoe. Instead, he said: ‘Sit and watch, sit and watch.’ For months and months, I did that.” As an adult, the Malaysian-born designer moved to London to attend college and then set up a small shop in London’s East End. He built a following of celebrity clients, including Princess Diana and Miss Piggy, who especially appreciated shopping in the tucked away shop.  Jimmy Choo’s reputation for style, craftsmanship, and surprising comfort caught the eye of a shoe-obsessed editor at British  , and the shop was transformed into an international brand. The shoes became so popular that  ’s fictional clotheshorse Carrie Bradshaw filled her closets with Choos, and it’s rumored that Cate Blanchett decided not to wear Choos to the 1999 Oscars because she feared they’d get more attention than she would. As the brand’s popularity exploded, accessories, menswear, and fragrances were added, and the brand has scooped up numerous awards including the British Fashion Council’s Accessory Designer of the Year in 2000, and Designer Brand of the Year in 2008. 47892070||Viktor & Rolf Spicebomb Eau de Toilette for Men; 1.7 Fl. Oz. This bold and sensual men’s fragrance by Viktor and Rolf is characterized by notes of bergamot, pink pepper, vetiver, tobacco and leather A statement-making fragrance, this bold fragrance with blended spices features sensual undertones that are ideal for day or nighttime wear. Ultrahip designers Viktor Horsting and Rolf Snoeren believe “fashion is an antidote to reality, it has the power of transformation and provides a window to a different, magical world.” This belief in fantasy has been apparent since the Dutch wunderkinds’ first Parisian show in 1993, where they upset couture ideals with a series of edgy, reconstructed ball gowns. The inventive designers gather inspiration from seemingly disparate sources—Golden Age portraiture, De Stijl functionalism, and experimental designers Elsa Schiaparelli and Yohji Yamamoto, among others—and weave them into complex architectural pieces that teeter between ready-to-wear and the avant-garde.  In recent years, the duo has moved away from the highly fantastical world of couture into a more mainstream presence. They developed a popular fragrance with L’Oréal and debuted a well-received collection at H&M. Horsting expanded on this when he said, “A fashion show is for an elite and this elite … will look for the new dress … of the season, which is what fashion’s about. But we would like fashion to be about more than that.” Top notes: bergamot, grapefruit, pink pepper and elemi Middle notes: saffron, cinnamon, and paprika Base notes: vetiver, tobacco, and leather Product volume: 1.7 Fl. Oz. Launched in 2012 ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Men's Fragrance
47717601||Burberry London Eau de Parfum for Women (1.7 Fl. Oz.) This perfume from 2006 features a classic floral scent that’s tame enough for the office yet still expressive of a feminine personality At his Hampshire shop in the 1850s, Thomas Burberry outfitted hunters and fishermen in rugged gear. Rain was a real misery for the outdoorsmen, so Burberry set out to create an alternative to an umbrella or the shade of an elephant. By 1888, he’d secured the patent for his design: a breathable cotton blend wound so tightly it could resist moisture and rips. Officially, it was called gabardine, but in common parlance, hunters, farmers, pub keepers, and even King Edward VII called it “Burberry.” At the onset of World War I, the inventor used the fabric for a waterproof trench coat literally for the trenches, fitted with the necessary epaulets and D-rings for an artillery-facing soldier. The trench’s style caught on and, decorated with Burberry’s signature tartan print, remains a staple of the brand today. Despite these ties to tradition, Burberry’s creative team lives by the motto  , Latin for “forward.” Classic time-tested shapes are updated with modern details such as statement buttons, metallic fabrics, and seasonal colors. White-floral perfume Opens up with rose, honeysuckle, and fruity tangerine notes Heart notes include jasmine, Tahitian gardenia, and soft peony Velvety trail of wood and musk Flacon wrapped in Burberry’s signature plaid print Launched in 2006 1.7 fl. oz. spray bottle ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance

A fragrance that’s both sweet and spicy, fruity and fresh, Legend Intense offers an amazingly versatile scent for all seasons With the majestic Alpine peak Mont Blanc as its guide, Montblanc has striven to be the pinnacle of luxury and style for more than 100 years. It all started in 1906 with an ingenious new writing tool, a “simple” pen with a built-in ink well. The fountain pen quickly gained a reputation as the best on the market, not just for its craftsmanship and dependability, but as a status symbol of style and culture. After decades of innovative marketing campaigns and global recognition, Montblanc has expanded its repertoire into leather goods, watches, jewelry, and cologne, cementing its status as purveyor of the world’s finest little luxuries. 43779146||Judith Leiber Amethyst Eau de Parfum for Women (2.5 Fl. Oz.) Eau de parfum inspired by the signature purple jewel in Judith Leiber’s jewelry features an elegant blend of floral and woodsy notes When World War II broke out, Judith Leiber, a native Hungarian, was forced away from her chemistry studies in London to become an apprentice at a high-end handbag factory. After the war, she moved to New York, where her eyes were opened to new ways she could add panache and embellishments to the humble accessory. With a drive to “make a bag look as good empty as it does stuffed,” Leiber invented the crystal-covered minaudièr, then moved on to crafting bags that looked like animals, fruits, and vegetables. Her coveted designs are so identifiable that curator Stacey Schmidt believes they transcend accessories to become “objets d’art.” And the retired designer seems to agree, as she maintains a museum of her life’s work on a quaint country road in the Hamptons. The eponymous businesswoman—and Presidential Medal of Freedom recipient—transformed her beauty business into an iconic enterprise that has stocked generations of home vanities across the globe. Just four skin products comprised the company’s inventory when Estée and her husband, Joseph, started selling in 1946. But today, Estée Lauder is a department-store staple and a worldwide network of stores. Whether drawing eyes to favorite facial features, or invisibly fighting the onset of fine lines, Estée Lauder makeup and products can help wearers feel their most beautiful. 48225341||Dolce & Gabbana Pour Femme Eau de Parfum for Women; 1.6 Fl. Oz. Sweet, but not overpowering, this fragrance blends fruity, floral, and sugary notes into an enticing scent that’s great for everyday wear Pour Femme blends fruity and floral notes with the sugary aroma of marshmallow to create a light and enticingly feminine scent that intrigues the senses without being overpowering. The names Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana are synonymous with high fashion, though that was not always the case. In the 1980s, the young designers corralled anyone they could into loft spaces and even fast-food restaurants (with burger-shaped invitations no less) they’d transformed into makeshift show rooms. From the beginning, “the boys” played with juxtaposition, contrasting masculine versus feminine, virgin versus harlot in the same designs. In ‘85, the pair made their Milan Fashion Week debut as part of a young talent showcase and never looked back. The international brand has made a name for itself by subverting fashion tropes. Corset dresses and leopard prints are transformed into sophisticated and wearable pieces. Perhaps most famously, the pair redefined women’s suiting with menswear-inspired shapes and tailoring. In addition to clothes, fragrances and other accessories perpetuate the brand’s baroque charm. Madonna, who recognized the pair early on and wore their designs for her 1993 Girlie Show tour commented “Their clothes are sexy with a sense of humor—like me.” Top: neroli, raspberry, and tangerine Heart: jasmine and orange blossom Base: marshmallow, vanilla, sandalwood, and heliotrope Introduced in 2012 1.6 fl. oz. spray bottle ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance

47957023||Lacoste Style in Play Eau de Toilette for Men (2.5 Fl. Oz.) Style in Play can impart an energy and an air of relaxed self-confidence to wearers with its masculine scent of green apple and pine tree Long before he invented the polo or coined the now-instantly-recognizable logo that brands them, Grand Slam tennis champion René Lacoste was given a curious nickname by the press. Never one to bow to traditional on-court attire, “The Alligator” proudly displayed his new persona through a small, embroidered version of the predatory animal on his tennis blazers. As an extension of this rebellion, he invented the polo shirt, believing there was a market for more casual short-sleeved shirts, instead of the dress shirts typically worn on court. Each would—and would continue to—bear the alligator insignia for which the tennis master was known. The company has continually produced its signature polo since 1933, but since then, Lacoste has evolved into a full line of athletic-inspired sportswear for men and women. Woody, slightly fruity fragrance Top notes: thuja and green apple Heart notes: cedar, jasmine, and pine tree Base notes: white musk, vetiver, and patchouli Released in 2004 2.5 fl. oz. spray bottle ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Men's Fragrance
47892058||Cartier Eau de Cartier Zeste de Soleil Eau de Toilette for Men and Women; 6.75 Fl. Oz. Bright and sunny fragrance with notes of passion fruit, mint, and yuzu works well on both men and women Cartier. The name alone evokes images of glamour and extravagance, often in the form of the Parisian jewelry house’s iconic emblem: the panther. This symbol emerged in the beginning of the 20th century, when exoticism was on the rise and Jeanne Toussaint, Cartier’s Director of Fine Jewelry, returned from an African safari with a passion for panthers. She began incorporating their likeness into everything from broaches to rings to cigarette cases. Perhaps her greatest achievement was a broach commissioned by the Duchess of Windsor that consisted of a diamond-studded panther curved around a 152.35-carat sapphire cabochon. Later iterations of the panther were made in three dimensions, with black onyx for spots, or with a “fur-setting” technique that used stones and intricately folded wires to mimic a panther’s coat. Today, Cartier continues to craft feline-inspired pieces that glow with emerald eyes, along with watches, scarves, and accessories that meld simple, geometric lines with stark color combinations. Fragrance for men and women Fragrance notes: passion fruit, mint, and yuzu Application: eau de toilette Capacity: 6.75 fl. oz. ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance

48307914||Giorgio Armani Acqua di Gio Profumo Eau de Parfum for Men; 1.35 Oz. or 2.5 Oz. Men’s fragrance with notes of sage, patchouli, bergamot, and aquatic accord In perfumery, an accord isn’t just one scent—it’s a grouping of notes that create a larger, standalone effect. An accord can be worn on its own, but it becomes extra special when it’s blended into a traditional perfume. Perfumers often turn to accords when they desire scents that can’t be bottled, such as green leaves or, as in this aquatic fragrance, the salty freshness of the sea. Giorgio Armani believed, “Elegance is not about being noticed, it’s about being remembered.” His eponymous fashion house embodies this philosophy, which planted Italian fashion firmly on the map. Relying on his eye for tailoring, Armani garbs men and women in sophisticated designs with a European sensuality, marked by simple silhouettes and opulent fabrics. His luxurious empire has expanded from a world-renowned fashion house into a powerful cultural identity. Sophia Loren once said, “Entering into Armani’s world is like landing into the peaceful eye of a typhoon, into the perfect calm, into a style that cannot be shaken by the winds of sensationalism.” Top notes: aquatic accord, bergamot Heart notes: geranium, sage, rosemary Base notes: patchouli, incense Choice of 1.35 fl. oz. or 2.5 fl. oz. Devotees stole ads from bus stations and demanded that stars like Marky Mark “drop trou” onstage to show off their Calvins. The designer gained notoriety for hypersuggestive commercials for everything from blue jeans to perfume, launching the careers of models like Brooke Shields and Kate Moss in the process. But what has kept his brand relevant for over 40 years is its classic, impeccably tailored clothing.   writes, “Klein always understood that the modern shopper wanted easy, versatile, and interchangeable separates to wear anywhere.” He made clothes for strong, confident American women—women who didn’t have time to put together elaborate outfits every morning. “I’m not doing costumes,” he said. “I believe in classic clothes—not the faddishness that looks right this season and is dead the next.” Oriental-spicy fragrance Top: green notes, mandarin orange, vanilla, peach, basil, bergamot, and lemon Middle notes: spices, coriander, sandalwood, orange blossom, jasmine, oakmoss, cedar, and rose Base notes: amber, musk, civet, vanilla, vetiver, and incense Bottle size: 3.4 fl. oz. 47938993||Yves Saint Laurent Opium Vapeurs de Parfum Eau de Toilette for Women (2.5 or 4.2 Fl. Oz.) This Mediterranean inspired fragrance features a mix of white floral and balsamic notes including jasmine, orange blossom, and incense In 1957, legendary designer Christian Dior calmly passed the reins of his eponymous fashion house to a remarkably young, 21-year-old Yves Saint Laurent. This single act kick-started the boy wonder’s enduring fashion legacy, and he launched his own line in 1962. During the decades that followed, his fame would skyrocket, propelled by groundbreaking, often controversial, designs that turned celebrities, fashion lovers, and fellow designers Miuccia Prada and Giorgio Armani into devout fans. Of his lasting influence, designer Christian Lacroix once quipped, “He’s got the form of Chanel with the opulence of Dior and the wit of Schiaparelli.” Saint Laurent was both lauded and slandered for this ingenuity and his often-paradoxical themes. Culling influence from cultural movements, the Beats, and political protests unfolding around the world during the ‘60s and ‘70s, Saint Laurent upset old-world fashion ideals with nearly every collection. He ruffled the feathers of the fashion elite by blending blue-collar garments such as peasant blouses and leather jackets with his couture works. He also outfitted women in tuxedoes and fedoras before it was common. His long-time partner, Pierre Berge, famously summed up Saint Laurent’s legacy in one turn-of-phrase: “Chanel gave women freedom. Yves Saint Laurent gave them power.” White floral and balsamic fragrance for women Inspired by the warmth and freshness of the Mediterranean Recommended for daytime wear Top: mandarin and pink pepper Heart: orange blossom and Sambac jasmine Base: incense, nutmeg, amber, vanilla, and light woods Launched in 2012 Peach and gold tone flacon ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance

The shoes became so popular that  ’s fictional clotheshorse Carrie Bradshaw filled her closets with Choos, and it’s rumored that Cate Blanchett decided not to wear Choos to the 1999 Oscars because she feared they’d get more attention than she would. 48122079||Burberry Sport Ice Eau de Toilette for Men; 1.7 Fl. Oz. Light citrus top notes float atop a base of cedar and amber in this fresh, assertive men’s eau de toilette from Burberry At his Hampshire shop in the 1850s, Thomas Burberry outfitted hunters and fishermen in rugged gear. Rain was a real misery for the outdoorsmen, so Burberry set out to create an alternative to an umbrella or the shade of an elephant. By 1888, he’d secured the patent for his design: a breathable cotton blend wound so tightly it could resist moisture and rips. Officially, it was called gabardine, but in common parlance, hunters, farmers, pub keepers, and even King Edward VII called it “Burberry.” At the onset of World War I, the inventor used the fabric for a waterproof trench coat literally for the trenches, fitted with the necessary epaulets and D-rings for an artillery-facing soldier. The trench’s style caught on and, decorated with Burberry’s signature tartan print, remains a staple of the brand today. Despite these ties to tradition, Burberry’s creative team lives by the motto  , Latin for “forward.” Classic time-tested shapes are updated with modern details such as statement buttons, metallic fabrics, and seasonal colors. 1.7 fl. oz. Spray bottle Top notes: citrus, ginger, and water Heart notes: sea water and juniper Base notes: musk, cedar, and amber Introduced in 2011 ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Men's Fragrance

48034090||Issey Miyake L'eau d'Issey Absolue Eau de Parfum for Women (3 Fl. Oz.) Bold, intense floral fragrance for women was inspired by both the amber glow of the setting sun and the jasmine flower as it blooms at night Issey Miyake doesn’t believe in fashion. He doesn’t believe in “gorgeous clothes.” Instead, he says, what he believes in is “a human being and a piece of cloth.” His first pieces were rooted in his native Japan, including revivals of traditional quilted pieces, such as the  , made from scraps, and the  . He began his work with the goal of breathing life back into Japan, which he saw “culturally obliterated” after the atomic bomb was dropped on his hometown of Hiroshima. He focused his designs on bright color, unique texture, and above all, functionality. After studying in Paris and New York, he began to experiment with pleating, working to twist and stitch in new and innovative ways. His goal was to find a pleat style that wouldn’t restrict movement and that would be easy to care for, and that gave birth to the Pleats Please line of apparel. In 1983, he told  , “I want to find out what clothing might be.” He has experimented with clothing the customers themselves cut at their preferred length, dresses that resemble paper lanterns, and two pairs of pants sewn together so you and your imaginary friend can be literally joined at the hip. Although his brand has appeared in   and Paris fashion shows every year since 1973, Miyake has always meant to appeal to a wider audience, emphasizing versatility and claiming the motto, “Clothes for everyone, not just a few.” Bright, intense floral fragrance for women Inspired by the amber light cast by the setting sun Launched in 2013 Freesia Lotus Jasmine Provence honey Tuberose Bourbon vanilla Precious woods Design house: Issey Miyake 3 fl. oz. eau de parfum spray ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance

It’s a whim. You don’t   it. You   it.” His rebellious designs have earned him seven CFDA awards, including Designer of the Year awards for menswear, women’s wear, and accessories, becoming the most nominated designer in CFDA history. 47673119||Dolce & Gabbana Rose The One Eau de Parfum for Women (1.6 Fl. Oz.) Fresh floral fragrance for women by Dolce and Gabbana features a blend of pink grapefruit, rose, lily, and peony The names Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana are synonymous with high fashion, though that was not always the case. In the 1980s, the young designers corralled anyone they could into loft spaces and even fast-food restaurants (with burger-shaped invitations no less) they’d transformed into makeshift show rooms. From the beginning, “the boys” played with juxtaposition, contrasting masculine versus feminine, virgin versus harlot in the same designs. In ‘85, the pair made their Milan Fashion Week debut as part of a young talent showcase and never looked back. The international brand has made a name for itself by subverting fashion tropes. Corset dresses and leopard prints are transformed into sophisticated and wearable pieces. Perhaps most famously, the pair redefined women’s suiting with menswear-inspired shapes and tailoring. In addition to clothes, fragrances and other accessories perpetuate the brand’s baroque charm. Madonna, who recognized the pair early on and wore their designs for her 1993 Girlie Show tour commented “Their clothes are sexy with a sense of humor—like me.” Fragrance for women by Dolce & Gabbana Top notes of black currant, pink grapefruit, and mandarin Heart notes of rose, litchi, peony and lily Base notes of sandalwood, musk, and vanilla Launched in 2009 1.6 fl. oz. ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance
48204046||My Burberry by Burberry Eau de Parfum for Women; 3 Fl. Oz. (Unboxed) Eau de parfum by Burberry with a day-friendly blend of notes such as bergamot, geranium, golden quince, and rose Recommended for daytime wear in the spring and fall At his Hampshire shop in the 1850s, Thomas Burberry outfitted hunters and fishermen in rugged gear. Rain was a real misery for the outdoorsmen, so Burberry set out to create an alternative to an umbrella or the shade of an elephant. By 1888, he’d secured the patent for his design: a breathable cotton blend wound so tightly it could resist moisture and rips. Officially, it was called gabardine, but in common parlance, hunters, farmers, pub keepers, and even King Edward VII called it “Burberry.” At the onset of World War I, the inventor used the fabric for a waterproof trench coat literally for the trenches, fitted with the necessary epaulets and D-rings for an artillery-facing soldier. The trench’s style caught on and, decorated with Burberry’s signature tartan print, remains a staple of the brand today. Despite these ties to tradition, Burberry’s creative team lives by the motto  , Latin for “forward.” Classic time-tested shapes are updated with modern details such as statement buttons, metallic fabrics, and seasonal colors. Top notes of sweet peas and bergamot Heart notes of geranium, freesia, and golden quince Base notes of patchouli, damask rose, and centifolia rose Eau de parfum for women Unboxed Launched in 2014 3 fl. oz. ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance

46728356||Prada Fragrance Miniatures Collection for Women (4-Piece) Test out a number of Prada’s most iconic fragrances with these miniatures, which include scents like Candy Florale and Infusion d’Iris In 1977, Miuccia Prada reluctantly gave up her dream of becoming a mime to take over her grandfather’s luggage shop. Founded in 1913, the Milanese shop was known for solid, heavy luggage that was so well thought of the Italian royal household granted Prada the use of its coat of arms. But the traditional trunks and bags were losing traction with the modern shopper. Miuccia designed a breakthrough product: a black nylon backpack, decorated only with an inverted triangle etched with the brand’s name. The bag took off.   writes, “the chic, stealth-status bags were seen slung over every fashionista’s shoulder.” Rapidly, Prada transformed into an international fashion force. Runway shows sparked industry trends, from avant-garde materials to daring color schemes. Instead, he said: ‘Sit and watch, sit and watch.’ For months and months, I did that.” As an adult, the Malaysian-born designer moved to London to attend college and then set up a small shop in London’s East End. He built a following of celebrity clients, including Princess Diana and Miss Piggy, who especially appreciated shopping in the tucked away shop.  Jimmy Choo’s reputation for style, craftsmanship, and surprising comfort caught the eye of a shoe-obsessed editor at British  , and the shop was transformed into an international brand. The shoes became so popular that  ’s fictional clotheshorse Carrie Bradshaw filled her closets with Choos, and it’s rumored that Cate Blanchett decided not to wear Choos to the 1999 Oscars because she feared they’d get more attention than she would. As the brand’s popularity exploded, accessories, menswear, and fragrances were added, and the brand has scooped up numerous awards including the British Fashion Council’s Accessory Designer of the Year in 2000, and Designer Brand of the Year in 2008. 48032429||Diane by Diane Von Furstenberg Eau de Toilette for Women (1.7 Fl. Oz.) Woody floral fragrance from the famed designer brings together notes of musk, patchouli, myrhh, and violet Diane von Furstenberg confesses to a complicated relationship with her best-known creation: the wrap dress. “I took it for granted, that little dress, even though it paid for all my bills, it paid for my children’s education, it paid for my houses, it paid everything,” she told NPR in 2014. But she has come to appreciate what her 1974 invention meant for millions of women. The dress required no zipper or snaps, simply slipping on or off. “You can go in a boardroom and make a presentation and feel feminine, and yet not exposed,” she told NPR. Today, she still sells plenty of wrap dresses in a variety of styles, as well as a wide variety of apparel and accessories. And she’s also turned her attention to philanthropy; she operates a family foundation with husband Barry Diller and supports charities such as St. Jude’s Children’s Research Hospital and Women for Women International. Founder Sotirio Bulgari came from an ancient family of Greek silversmiths; today, third generation family members carry on the family tradition of transforming raw precious elements into sparkling statement necklaces. Each piece begins with a sketch, as designers assess the color, brilliance, wearability, and je ne sais quoi. In an interview with the  , Nicola Bulgari said, “Each piece has its own philosophy.” Though he draws inspiration from architecture around the world—from India to Columbus, Indiana—he says, “I don’t like the idea of a global style … the same things all over the world. Devotees stole ads from bus stations and demanded that stars like Marky Mark “drop trou” onstage to show off their Calvins. The designer gained notoriety for hypersuggestive commercials for everything from blue jeans to perfume, launching the careers of models like Brooke Shields and Kate Moss in the process. But what has kept his brand relevant for over 40 years is its classic, impeccably tailored clothing.   writes, “Klein always understood that the modern shopper wanted easy, versatile, and interchangeable separates to wear anywhere.” He made clothes for strong, confident American women—women who didn’t have time to put together elaborate outfits every morning. “I’m not doing costumes,” he said. “I believe in classic clothes—not the faddishness that looks right this season and is dead the next.” 3.4 fl. oz. eau de toilette spray 2.6oz. deodorant stick Spicy, woody scent Opens with aromas of mandarin, cardamom, and rum Pepper, Egyptian jasmine, patchouli, and cognac form the heart Settles on woody nuances of oud, Atlas cedar, and musk Fragrance launched in 2012 ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Men's Fragrance

12572108||BCBGMaxazria or BCBGMaxazria Bon Genre Eau de Parfum for Women; 3.4 Fl. Oz. Fragrances with notes of berries and soft florals: BCBGMaxazria with cherry and violet notes, or Bon Genre with raspberry and orange blossom These classic fragrances bring out two slightly different sides of BCBGMaxazria. The eponymous fragrance is soft and charming, with notes of cherry, violet, and grounding orris root. Bon Genre is designed for confidence and vitality with a more complex layering of notes: fruity mango and raspberry top notes, a balanced orange-blossom and peony heart, and an earthy base of woods and white musk. “Bon chic, bon genre,” Parisian slang for “good style, good attitude” is what BCBG stands for, both literally and figuratively. Max Azria founded the brand in 1989, though it truly came into it’s own when Azria’s wife Lubov joined the team in 1991. What began as a brand for modern women quickly branched out into many distinct apparel lines. BCBGeneration epitomizes the casual, bohemian-chic aesthetic, while the upscale Max Azria Collection injects power and femininity into professional and casual chic clothing. In addition to apparel and shoes, the brand has a full accessory line running the gambit from sunglasses to watches to handbags. The husband-and-wife’s collaborations grace the windows of more than 550 BCBG MAXAZRIA boutiques dotting the planet that has all the oceans and people on it. Mr. Bahama relishes travel. He’s brown as a nut. He can charm people in dozens of languages. And he’s entirely fictional.  Still, the mythical man’s spirit steers the Tommy Bahama brand, which embodies an idyllic, unhurried island lifestyle. The brand started out selling printed silk shirts and tailored pants—the unofficial uniform of island visitors. A fusion of laid-back style and high quality drew loyal customers, who can buy Tommy Bahama furniture and housewares and even dine at in-store restaurants. 47814089||Dolce by Dolce & Gabbana Eau de Pafum for Women (1.6 Fl. Oz. or 2.5 Fl. Oz.) Inspired by the beauty of Sicily, this fragrance smells like a gentle breeze flowing through a garden of white flowers The names Domenico Dolce and Stefano Gabbana are synonymous with high fashion, though that was not always the case. In the 1980s, the young designers corralled anyone they could into loft spaces and even fast-food restaurants (with burger-shaped invitations no less) they’d transformed into makeshift show rooms. From the beginning, “the boys” played with juxtaposition, contrasting masculine versus feminine, virgin versus harlot in the same designs. In ‘85, the pair made their Milan Fashion Week debut as part of a young talent showcase and never looked back. The international brand has made a name for itself by subverting fashion tropes. Corset dresses and leopard prints are transformed into sophisticated and wearable pieces. Perhaps most famously, the pair redefined women’s suiting with menswear-inspired shapes and tailoring. In addition to clothes, fragrances and other accessories perpetuate the brand’s baroque charm. Madonna, who recognized the pair early on and wore their designs for her 1993 Girlie Show tour commented “Their clothes are sexy with a sense of humor—like me.” Soft, feminine scent teeming with white flowers Inspired by the beauty of Sicily Launched in 2014 Top notes: neroli leaf and papaya flower Heart notes: white amaryllis, narcissus, and white water lily Base notes: cashmere and musk Design house: Dolce & Gabbana 1.6 or 2.5 fl. oz. eau de parfum spray ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance

47903361||Jimmy Choo Man Eau de Toilette (3.3 Fl. Oz.) With its extremely likable scent, Jimmy Choo Man endears itself to even novice noses, which makes it a great cologne for everyday wear When Jimmy Choo made his first pair of shoes at age 11, the task was long overdue. “When I first started,” he said, “My father wouldn’t let me make a shoe. Instead, he said: ‘Sit and watch, sit and watch.’ For months and months, I did that.” As an adult, the Malaysian-born designer moved to London to attend college and then set up a small shop in London’s East End. He built a following of celebrity clients, including Princess Diana and Miss Piggy, who especially appreciated shopping in the tucked away shop. Jimmy Choo’s reputation for style, craftsmanship, and surprising comfort caught the eye of a shoe-obsessed editor at British  , and the shop was transformed into an international brand. The shoes became so popular that  ’s fictional clotheshorse Carrie Bradshaw filled her closets with Choos, and it’s rumored that Cate Blanchett decided not to wear Choos to the 1999 Oscars because she feared they’d get more attention than she would. As the brand’s popularity exploded, accessories, menswear, and fragrances were added, and the brand has scooped up numerous awards including the British Fashion Council’s Accessory Designer of the Year in 2000, and Designer Brand of the Year in 2008. Roy Halston Frowick (1932-1990) didn’t take long to get his fashion designs into the national consciousness. At President John F. Kennedy’s inauguration in 1961, Jacqueline Kennedy wore a hat designed by Halston, and soon he had a client list that included Liza Minnelli, Marlene Dietrich, Elizabeth Taylor, and Anjelica Huston. His innovations included the durable, washable ultra-suede, as well as the halter dress, a sleek, elongated number that fits comfortably into discotheques, such as his beloved Studio 54. 46464571||Burberry Touch Eau de Toilette for Men (3.3 Fl. Oz.) Fresh, woody eau de toilette spray for men evokes the clean, simple air of a barber shop with notes of artemisia, white pepper, and cedar At his Hampshire shop in the 1850s, Thomas Burberry outfitted hunters and fishermen in rugged gear. Rain was a real misery for the outdoorsmen, so Burberry set out to create an alternative to an umbrella or the shade of an elephant. By 1888, he’d secured the patent for his design: a breathable cotton blend wound so tightly it could resist moisture and rips. Officially, it was called gabardine, but in common parlance, hunters, farmers, pub keepers, and even King Edward VII called it “Burberry.” At the onset of World War I, the inventor used the fabric for a waterproof trench coat literally for the trenches, fitted with the necessary epaulets and D-rings for an artillery-facing soldier. The trench’s style caught on and, decorated with Burberry’s signature tartan print, remains a staple of the brand today. Despite these ties to tradition, Burberry’s creative team lives by the motto  , Latin for “forward.” Classic time-tested shapes are updated with modern details such as statement buttons, metallic fabrics, and seasonal colors. Top notes of artemisia, violet leaf, and mandarin orange Heart notes of nutmeg, white pepper, and cedar Base notes of tonka bean, vetiver, and white musk FiFi Award: 2001 Fragrance of the Year, Men’s Prestige “My overall impression of Touch for Men is of cleanness — not only the clean lathers and talcum powders of a barber shop, but the clean smell of freshly laundered clothes, dried outdoors in summer sunshine.” -  Woody floral musk fragrance for men Introduced in 2000 Created by perfumer Jean-Pierre Bethouart 3.3 fl. oz. eau de toilette spray ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Men's Fragrance

Wear this classic citrus-floral aroma everyday to remind yourself of what’s truly eternal in your life After Marty crash lands in the 1950s in the 1985 flick  , girls call him “Calvin,” thanks to his purple Calvin Klein briefs with their signature, designer-stamped waistband. One adoring girl breathes, “I’ve never seen purple underwear before.” Just three years before the movie, Calvin Klein underwear had premiered to a great uproar. Devotees stole ads from bus stations and demanded that stars like Marky Mark “drop trou” onstage to show off their Calvins. The designer gained notoriety for hypersuggestive commercials for everything from blue jeans to perfume, launching the careers of models like Brooke Shields and Kate Moss in the process. But what has kept his brand relevant for over 40 years is its classic, impeccably tailored clothing.   writes, “Klein always understood that the modern shopper wanted easy, versatile, and interchangeable separates to wear anywhere.” He made clothes for strong, confident American women—women who didn’t have time to put together elaborate outfits every morning. “I’m not doing costumes,” he said. “I believe in classic clothes—not the faddishness that looks right this season and is dead the next.” Designed as a tribute to marriage, this citrus-spicy-floral scent is ideal for every day wear Top note: citrus, green notes, mandarin orange, freesia, sage Heart note: lily, carnation, violet, jasmine, marigold, lily-of-the-valley, rose, narcissus Base note: sandalwood, amber, patchouli, musk, heliotrope 3.4oz. 47870828||Yves Saint Laurent La Nuit de L'homme Le Parfum for Men; 3.3 fl. oz. Fresh notes of bergamot and lavender mix with vetiver to create a warm, inviting fragrance that men can wear as their signature scent In 1957, legendary designer Christian Dior calmly passed the reins of his eponymous fashion house to a remarkably young, 21-year-old Yves Saint Laurent. This single act kick-started the boy wonder’s enduring fashion legacy, and he launched his own line in 1962. During the decades that followed, his fame would skyrocket, propelled by groundbreaking, often controversial, designs that turned celebrities, fashion lovers, and fellow designers Miuccia Prada and Giorgio Armani into devout fans. Of his lasting influence, designer Christian Lacroix once quipped, “He’s got the form of Chanel with the opulence of Dior and the wit of Schiaparelli.” Saint Laurent was both lauded and slandered for this ingenuity and his often-paradoxical themes. Culling influence from cultural movements, the Beats, and political protests unfolding around the world during the ‘60s and ‘70s, Saint Laurent upset old-world fashion ideals with nearly every collection. He ruffled the feathers of the fashion elite by blending blue-collar garments such as peasant blouses and leather jackets with his couture works. He also outfitted women in tuxedoes and fedoras before it was common. His long-time partner, Pierre Berge, famously summed up Saint Laurent’s legacy in one turn-of-phrase: “Chanel gave women freedom. Yves Saint Laurent gave them power.” Top notes: bergamot, anise, and pepper Middle notes: lavender, french labdanum, and fruity notes Base notes: vetiver, patchouli, and vanilla Launched in 2010 Application: parfum spray Bottle size: 3.3 fl. oz. ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Men's Fragrance
48413478||Prada Amber pour Homme Eau de Toilette (3.4 Fl. Oz.) Prada’s first men’s fragrance is an oriental composition based on amber, accented by prominent notes of saffron, myrrh, and vanilla Miuccia Prada played an active role in creating of this perfume. Maybe due this or the feminine touch of the perfumer Daniela Roche-Andrier, this is a non-aggressive fragrance of elegance and gentle masculinity. In 1977, Miuccia Prada reluctantly gave up her dream of becoming a mime to take over her grandfather’s luggage shop. Founded in 1913, the Milanese shop was known for solid, heavy luggage that was so well thought of the Italian royal household granted Prada the use of its coat of arms. But the traditional trunks and bags were losing traction with the modern shopper. Miuccia designed a breakthrough product: a black nylon backpack, decorated only with an inverted triangle etched with the brand’s name. The bag took off.   writes, “the chic, stealth-status bags were seen slung over every fashionista’s shoulder.” Rapidly, Prada transformed into an international fashion force. Runway shows sparked industry trends, from avant-garde materials to daring color schemes. Though her chic, bold styles evolve with the seasons, Bloomingdale’s Kal Ruttenstein said, “Prada is totally monumental. She leads everyone.” Oriental amber accord, along with notes of vanilla, labdanum, tonka bean, and patchouli Aromatic, slightly soapy fougère accord, with notes of pelargonium, vetiver, orange blossom, and myrrh Cologne accord of citrusy bergamot, mandarin, neroli, and cardamom Leather accord, along with saffron and sandalwood notes Size of bottle: 3.4 fl. oz. 46294535||Burberry Men's and Women's Fragrances This selection offers some of Burberry’s most popular fragrances, including award-winning scents such as Brit and Touch At his Hampshire shop in the 1850s, Thomas Burberry outfitted hunters and fishermen in rugged gear. Rain was a real misery for the outdoorsmen, so Burberry set out to create an alternative to an umbrella or the shade of an elephant. By 1888, he’d secured the patent for his design: a breathable cotton blend wound so tightly it could resist moisture and rips. Officially, it was called gabardine, but in common parlance, hunters, farmers, pub keepers, and even King Edward VII called it “Burberry.” At the onset of World War I, the inventor used the fabric for a waterproof trench coat literally for the trenches, fitted with the necessary epaulets and D-rings for an artillery-facing soldier. The trench’s style caught on and, decorated with Burberry’s signature tartan print, remains a staple of the brand today. Despite these ties to tradition, Burberry’s creative team lives by the motto  , Latin for “forward.” Classic time-tested shapes are updated with modern details such as statement buttons, metallic fabrics, and seasonal colors. Oriental woody fragrance FiFi Awards: 2005 Fragrance of the Year, Men’s Prestige Top notes of mandarin, bergamot, ginger, and cardamom Heart notes of cedar and nutmeg with a touch of refined wild rose 48330457||Tom Ford Black Orchid Eau de Parfum for Women (3.4 Fl. Oz.) Dark and sumptuous oriental-chypre fragrance for women incorporates luxurious notes of black orchid, black truffle, and French jasmine Anchoring this sumptuous fragrance is black orchid, a luxury ingredient that’s custom grown and very rare. Along with woodsy notes at the base, the orchid offers a dark earthiness that’s offset by sweet, creamy notes of vanilla and citrus. Eau de parfum fragrances assert themselves by diffusing into the air more aggressively than other scents; they can be almost twice as concentrated as eau de toilettes. They can also intensify when exposed to body heat, so a little bit can end up going a long way. “Very well done, has personality to spare, and evokes a kind of grownup glamour that is very appealing.” –  In 2005, after a decade-long stint at Gucci, Tom Ford launched his eponymous brand. In addition to a collection of optical frames and sunglasses, he partnered with Estée Lauder to produce a beauty line with fragrances and cosmetics. Next, he launched a menswear and accessory collection and opened his New York flagship store, whose doors appear only by tapping a certain nondescript brick four times. His women’s-wear collection debuted with participation from style icons such as Lauren Hutton and Beyoncé. In addition to winning five separate honors from the Council of Fashion Designers of America, Ford has snagged British  ’s International Man of the Year Award, title of Best Fashion Designer by   Magazine,   USA’s Designer of the Year, and   Russia’s Man of the Decade. 47713230||Calvin Klein Obsession Summer for Women or Men Fresh, brand new fragrances from Calvin Klein are uniquely suited to the summer months After Marty crash lands in the 1950s in the 1985 flick  , girls call him “Calvin,” thanks to his purple Calvin Klein briefs with their signature, designer-stamped waistband. One adoring girl breathes, “I’ve never seen purple underwear before.” Just three years before the movie, Calvin Klein underwear had premiered to a great uproar. Devotees stole ads from bus stations and demanded that stars like Marky Mark “drop trou” onstage to show off their Calvins. The designer gained notoriety for hypersuggestive commercials for everything from blue jeans to perfume, launching the careers of models like Brooke Shields and Kate Moss in the process. But what has kept his brand relevant for over 40 years is its classic, impeccably tailored clothing.   writes, “Klein always understood that the modern shopper wanted easy, versatile, and interchangeable separates to wear anywhere.” He made clothes for strong, confident American women—women who didn’t have time to put together elaborate outfits every morning. “I’m not doing costumes,” he said. “I believe in classic clothes—not the faddishness that looks right this season and is dead the next.” Women’s fragrance thrives in warm weather Notes include bergamot, white patchouli, and white musk Launched in 2016 3.4 fl. oz. eau de toilette spray Men’s fragrance suited for the summer months Notes include artemisia, blue sage, and cedar Launched in 2016 4.2 fl. oz. eau de parfum spray ||Health & Beauty > Fragrance > Women's Fragrance

48307083||Kenneth Cole Men's Body Spray (6 Fl. Oz.) Men’s fragrances with masculine bases of amber, musk, or suede and refreshing top notes that include citrus, mint, ginger, or lavender On his first day in business, Kenneth Cole parked a 40-foot trailer, director, camera, and troop of actresses in Midtown Manhattan, just across the street from the Hilton. Somebody had painted “Kenneth Cole Productions, Inc.” on the side of the trailer. Nobody had loaded film into the camera. The movie was a ruse—a way for the young designer to get a coveted parking permit and set up his mobile shoe store in the heart of New York. It worked. In less than three days, he sold 40,000 pairs of shoes. More than two decades later, Kenneth Cole has expanded his line beyond high-quality high-fashion shoes to include trendy apparel, handbags, and watches for men and women around the world. He’s known for updating classic looks with modern details, such as adding a wedge heel to a pair of pointed-toe boots or making sure that a watch can tell the current time on Jupiter. 48327956||Givenchy Dahlia Noir Eau de Toilette for Women (1 or 2.5 Fl. Oz.) In presenting notes of peach and lemon, flowers and vanilla, this perfume gives off a feminine mix of aromas lovely enough for everyday wear Even before Hubert de Givenchy launched his now-renowned design house, the Paris fashion world recognized his talent. In the late 1940s, the legendary Christian Dior recommended Givenchy to another designer even though Dior was secretly hoping to poach Givenchy for his own house when it opened the following year. But in 1952, Givenchy launched his own line to much praise, and it was Spanish designer Cristóbal Balenciaga—not Dior—who took the fashion world’s “L’enfant terrible” under his wing. Together, Balenciaga and Givenchy honed Givenchy’s eye for purity of form. In one of fashion’s wisest marketing moves, Givenchy dressed his friend and muse, Audrey Hepburn, both on- and offscreen at the height of her career, and First Lady Jackie Kennedy became something of a poster girl for his trim coats and slim little black dresses. Givenchy has also been credited with the invention of the chemise sack dress and the princess silhouette. Today, the house continues to stay relevant under the direction of Riccardo Tisci, winning the 2013 CFDA International award for outstanding creative contribution to the fashion world. Daytime fragrance spritzes the wearer with a delicate bouquet of floral notes that fade into a powdery blend of iris, musk, and sandalwood Recommended for the office or subtle daytime wear Spelled with a   but pronounced as a  , the Bvlgari brand began as a small silver shop in Rome in 1884. Founder Sotirio Bulgari came from an ancient family of Greek silversmiths; today, third generation family members carry on the family tradition of transforming raw precious elements into sparkling statement necklaces. Each piece begins with a sketch, as designers assess the color, brilliance, wearability, and je ne sais quoi. In an interview with the  , Nicola Bulgari said, “Each piece has its own philosophy.” Though he draws inspiration from architecture around the world—from India to Columbus, Indiana—he says, “I don’t like the idea of a global style … the same things all over the world. The multitalented Texan knows music, movies, and a lot about fashion. She started small, designing a line of edible beauty products, and worked her way up to a full-blown clothing, shoes, accessories, and home decor empire. Her designs are known for their approachable, girl-next-door appeal. The label tends toward casual styles that are trendy, but wearable and more affordable than most celebrity labels. “She has a keen insight into what her customers want: exceptional value,” says powerhouse shoe designer and collaborator Vince Camuto. “She’s involved in everything from selecting materials to determining the prints and styles that work best for a woman’s body.” Not one to shy away from statement items herself, Simpson also mixes in glamorous pieces like oversized sunglasses and animal-print accessories.
